Former wrestling head coach J Robinson oversees a practice on September 18, 2012. 
Evidence suggests a University of Minnesota Athletics Department administrator and several staff members knew of at least one wrestler using and selling drugs as early as December 2015 — about three months before a University internal investigation said the department and wrestling coaches became aware of a drug problem on the team. 
Senior Associate Athletics Director Marc Ryan sent an email on Dec. 7, 2015 to former wrestling head coach J Robinson, current interim head coach Brandon Eggum, assistant coach Luke Becker and trainer Rich Schlotfeldt alerting them to an unspecified incident possibly requiring further investigation by a University athletics drug and alcohol committee, the University of Minnesota Police Department’s investigation file shows. The files were obtained by the Minnesota Daily through a data request. 
That same day, an email sent by Ryan suggested he “had known that the unlawful use, sale, or possession of drugs was a problem for at least one student,” according to an examination of electronic records completed on behalf of UMPD. The email referenced in the electronic records report was completely redacted by the University. 
And communications from that day reference "'orange pills' possessed by one student," though the sender of those messages isn’t included in the heavily-redacted report. 
But Ryan told police he was "first informed that there was suspected drug activity on the wrestling team" in mid-March according to documents detailing the investigation into the sale and use of Xanax by University wrestlers. 
The University first learned of the problem in early April through an anonymous report, triggering a police investigation of the drug ring, according to the findings of a school investigation released the same day Robinson was fired. 
The University’s official report admits to staff-wide knowledge of the drug problem in March, but it doesn’t mention that evidence suggested Ryan and other staff knew months earlier. 
Coaching and athletic department staff purposely limited electronic communication, according to the examination of electronic records completed for UMPD. 
“Several messages indicate that coaching and athletic department staff wished to keep their electronic communication limited,” the electronic records report noted. 
Robinson’s University email account showed no activity throughout most of March. 
“The only way that there would be no activity in an email account is if the user deleted all of the emails,” University Information Services told police investigators. 
A University Athletics spokesman declined to comment for this story. 
Culture of troubling behavior 
Robinson was fired Sept. 7 after the University determined that he refused to cooperate with attempts to investigate his team’s drug problem to shield members from consequences for selling and distributing Xanax, a prescription anti-anxiety medication. 
Robinson had coached at the University for nearly 30 years, guiding the team to three national championships. 
The University disclosed letters of apology written by four of 14 accused wrestlers. The letters detail accounts of theft, gambling and fighting by team members. A team-wide drug test showed three members tested positive — one for marijuana and two for amphetamines. 
But the drug test — scheduled two days after the end of the wrestling season — did not test for Xanax. Wrestlers were informed after the test was administered that it would not check for the drug at the center of the criminal investigation. 
Though Robinson offered amnesty to wrestlers who self-reported to him, University attorney Brent Benrud said in a letter to Athletics Director Mark Coyle that it was unlikely the wrestlers met the self-reporting requirements of the Safe Harbor program, a voluntary disclosure process that protects students who admit to drug use from being tested. 
The Drug Testing Review Board determines whether athletes meet the Safe Harbor requirements, though the policy does not cover students involved in the sale of drugs. 
The anonymous University wrestler who tipped off the investigation said a teammate showed him video evidence of wrestlers receiving "500-1000s" of pills by mail from a former wrestler who transferred to Old Dominion University in Virginia. 
In February 2016, Old Dominion staff found him passed out in a study area with a firearm in his backpack. He is no longer a student at the school. 
A University Office of the General Counsel document showed that several team members turned in drugs to Robinson, including Xanax, marijuana, Adderall and oxycodone — to which Robinson said, “Holy shit, I did not think you had this much.” 
Wrestlers either declined or could not be reached for comment. 
Leaders of the drug ring accused of selling or taking drugs were first- or second-year wrestlers. All of the first- and second-year wrestlers lived in the 17th Avenue Residence Hall. 
Police led an investigation into hundreds of package receipts for mail sent to the residence hall. 
Four team members were named as the distributors of the drug. 
Every one of the 14 wrestlers named by the anonymous reporter as users or sellers of the drug are listed on the school’s 2016-17 wrestling roster.

title: Driver allegedly caught with pot, $71,000
story:
A Twin Cities man allegedly was caught with marijuana and over $70,000 during a traffic stop on Highway 169. 
A Nicollet County sheriff's deputy stopped Jeremiah Devon Saeger, 23, of Blaine, for not having a license plate Tuesday afternoon in St. Peter. The vehicle was searched because it smelled of marijuana and Saeger admitted he had a marijuana pipe, according to the criminal complaint. 
Authorities said they found a quart-size baggie with 116 grams of marijuana, multiple baggies with marijuana residue, a scale and other paraphernalia. 
In a small safe there reportedly was over $71,000. The cash included three counterfeit $100 bills. 
Saeger allegedly admitted he smokes marijuana daily but said he is not a dealer. 
He told authorities the money was given to him by a friend to pay for college. He said he didn't know this friend's name, the complaint said. 
Saeger was charged Thursday in Nicollet County Court with felony counts of drug sales and drug possession.

title: Tip leads to large marijuana growing operation near Gibbon
story:
An anonymous tip led to the discovery of a large marijuana growing operation in rural Sibley County. 
Authorities reportedly found 157 marijuana plants, nearly 8 pounds of cultivated marijuana, and marijuana wax and edibles on a farmstead at 62428 220th St. north of Gibbon on Tuesday. 
Marc Alan Gauquie, 40, lives at the property and was charged Thursday in Sibley County District Court with felony drug sales. 
The Sibley County Sheriff's Office received an anonymous letter in the mail in June alleging Gauquie was growing marijuana. 
A sheriff's investigator subpoenaed records from the power company that services the property and found it was using significantly more electricity than neighboring farms, according to a search warrant application. 
A member of the State Patrol conducted aerial surveillance of the property Monday and observed what appeared to be marijuana growing in a wooded area of the property, the warrant alleges. 
When authorities, with a warrant, searched the property Tuesday, they allegedly found marijuana inside and outside the residence. 
Marijuana allegedly was found in the area identified by the trooper. There also was marijuana and marijuana growing equipment in every room of the residence, according to the criminal complaint. 
Authorities said they found a total of 7.8 pounds of raw marijuana, 157 marijuana plants, 13 grams of marijuana wax and 58 candy bars containing marijuana. 
Gauquie was jailed and was released on bail. 
It's not the first time Gauquie allegedly has been caught growing marijuana. He pleaded guilty to felony drug sales after more than 300 pot plants were seized from him in 2009 in Kandiyohi County.

title: Dealer who sold pot to fund tuition sentenced
story:
A Mankato drug dealer caught with 3 pounds of marijuana was sentenced to two months in jail and two months of house arrest. 
Lawrence Andrew Stutsman, 26, was convicted of felony drug sales Wednesday in Blue Earth County District Court. Additional drug charges were dismissed in a plea deal. 
Stutsman sold over a pound of marijuana to a police informant for $2,500 in October, according to the criminal complaint. Then a Minnesota State University student, Stutsman told the informant he was using the money to help pay for school. 
Authorities then searched Stutsman's apartment and found another 2 pounds of marijuana, 23 grams of ecstasy and a handgun. 
Stutsman was sentenced Wednesday to 60 days in jail followed by 60 days of home confinement and then five years of probation. The charge will be reduced to a misdemeanor if he completes the terms of the sentence.

title: Over 1 pound of marijuana allegedly found in New Ulm home
story:
NEW ULM â€” A New Ulm man is facing felony charges after a large amount of marijuana allegedly was found in his residence along with a child. 
The Brown-Lyon-Redwood-Renville Drug Task Force searched a mobile home on North Broadway Street on June 6 after an informant said one of its occupants, Josh Duane Paulson, 36, had a large amount of marijuana. 
Agents found 1.5 pounds of marijuana and some marijuana wax in two bedrooms, according to a criminal complaint. A young child was in the living room. 
Paulson allegedly told police he purchases marijuana in bulk to save money and uses it to control his pain and anxiety. One of Paulson's personal care attendants told police Paulson told her he sells marijuana. 
Paulson was charged with felony counts of drug sales and drug possession Tuesday in Brown County District Court.

title: With medical cannabis, only high for hopefuls is cost
story:
Jason Bennett was hoping Minnesota's medical cannabis program could help his daughter, Ashlyn. She has Rett syndrome, a condition that causes seizures, but the family realized the program is unaffordable for them and many others. Photo by Pat Christman 
MaryAnn Nelson of Mankato kissed her daughter Rachael's hand during a House of Representatives committee meeting to review a bill for medical marijuana. Rachael suffers from Rett syndrome, a rare brain disorder that causes seizures. The Nelsons and other local families are now unable to afford the costly treatment, as insurance doesn't cover it. File photo from The Associated Press 
MANKATO — After all her work pushing for legalized medical cannabis in Minnesota, MaryAnn Nelson doesn’t even have her daughter enrolled in the program. 
A year ago the Mankato mother and her daughter, Rachael, became something like the faces of the local push for medical cannabis. They and other families of children with Rett syndrome, a condition causing daily seizures, hoped legalization would lead to much needed relief. 
The reason the Nelsons aren’t signed up isn’t because medical cannabis doesn’t work. It’s because they can’t afford it. And they’re not alone. 
Several area families of children with Rett syndrome haven’t been able to sign up due to exorbitant costs that insurance won’t cover. 
Nelson said her daughter’s treatment would cost $500 a month. As a single mother, that price is too steep. 
“My other children know that seizures are a part of life and I prefer that they didn’t know they were part of life,” she said. “There’s a medicine out there and I just wish we could afford it.” 
Like others in the area, Nelson said she experienced sticker shock once the medical cannabis program started. 
Jason Bennett, of Mankato, said his daughter, Ashlyn, tried the CBD, or cannabidoil meds, for a couple months last year. The cost doubled after one month once the dosage was increased, and the uncertainty of cost from month to month forced them to drop out. 
“I can’t even get to the point of seeing if it works because it’s cost prohibitive,” Bennett said. 
On top of the cost, the accessibility was a major issue for the Bennetts. They had to drive to LeafLine Labs in Eagan to fill out their prescriptions. 
Bennett said it’s frustrating to be able to fill out a prescription down the street for a range of other medications, but then have to drive more than an hour for another legal medication. To him, it further feeds into the stigma still attached to marijuana as a medicine. 
“It makes you feel like you’re doing something wrong, and at the end of the day I’m trying to make my daughter better,” he said. 
Concerns like these aren’t limited to the Mankato area. A recent survey from the Minnesota Department of Health found 73 percent of respondents reported the cost of medical cannabis to be unaffordable. 
Meanwhile, 90 percent of those surveyed reported “mild to significant” benefits paired with few side effects. 
Michelle Larson, director of the Minnesota Department of Health's office of medical cannabis, said she wasn’t surprised by the effectiveness of treatment or the costs. 
Medical cannabis, like many other prescription medications, is expensive when it has to be paid for out of pocket, she said. 
“We know that costs are prohibitive and we are concerned about it,” she said. 
Nelson said her insurance doesn't cover medical cannabis because of its status as a Schedule I controlled substance under federal law. Despite medical cannabis being legal in half the states, federal law considers it to serve no medical purpose. 
Minnesota, like most states with medical marijuana, does not regulate the prices set by the companies who manufacture, market and distribute the medicine — LeafLine Labs and Minnesota Medical Solutions are the two manufacturers approved in the state. 
At least one state, New York, does regulate prices for its medical cannabis program. There, registered organizations submit costs to the state program. 
The commissioner then determines whether the prices are reasonable once the cost of production and profit is taken into account. Prices reported in New York, however, weren’t much cheaper than the prices cited by Nelson and Bennett. 
Dan Brinkhaus, a New Prague parent who founded the Minnesota Rett Syndrome Research Association, said it's discouraging to hear about costs when the effects of medical cannabis are so encouraging. 
“We’ve heard big success stories around medical marijuana,” he said. “(The cost) really is frustrating.” 
Just like Bennett and Nelson, Brinkhaus isn’t able to afford the treatment for his child. The parents still maintain hope that their loved ones will be able to experience the benefits, even if they know it might not be anytime soon. 
Nelson’s daughter did qualify for a trial in which she’d receive a year’s worth of treatment. The timeline keeps getting pushed back though, Nelson said. 
Bennett, meanwhile, said he’s looking to the legislature to take the necessary steps to help make sure the program is affordable. He and other local families are regularly in touch with Rep. Clark Johnson regarding their concerns. 
Although it’s not clear what can be done at this point to address accessibility and cost, Johnson said it’s certainly a big enough concern to explore further. 
“It’s something that’s important to a number of my constituents, and it needs that kind of energy through the rest of the state to have a serious discussion,” he said. 
After saying the program has had an encouraging start, he wondered if the Legislature was perhaps overly cautious in crafting the bill. 
Although it’s tough seeing his daughter have multiple seizures per day knowing medical cannabis could help, Bennett said all he can do for now is practice patience. 
“What’s happened has been a good step forward but there’s a long way to go,” he said. “I would say what I’d really like to see is have it be treated like any kind of medication.” 
Follow Brian Arola @BrianArolaMFP.

title: Marijuana, meth still the top local drugs in '17
story:
Marijuana is still king among Mankato-area drug users, methamphetamine is still the most destructive, and the opioid epidemic plaguing other parts of America is still not a widespread problem locally, according to statistics from the Minnesota River Valley Drug Task Force. 
The task force — which covers Blue Earth, Nicollet, Watonwan and Martin counties — made 165 drug-related arrests in 2017, said task force Cmdr. Jeff Wersal. That's a 10 percent jump from the previous year, and the total number of cases handled rose a similar amount. 
"For the last five or six years, it's the most cases," Wersal said. 
The growth could indicate growing illegal drug use, but it could also reflect additional enforcement efforts by the task force, which added a fifth officer in 2017, he said. 
The numbers didn't show any major changes in drug preference such as skyrocketing use of heroin or opioids such as hydrocodone, oxycodone, morphine, fentanyl and codeine that have devastated other regions of the United States. 
"I don't know why, because Rochester's got a problem, so does the metro and so does northern Minnesota," Wersal said. 
Among other work, the task force attempts to set up buys from drug dealers using undercover officers or cooperating informants. 
"Heroin is just tough to find," he said. 
Fewer than 4 grams of heroin (about one-seventh of an ounce) were seized or purchased in undercover drug buys by the task force in the four counties last year, which compares to 14,574 grams of marijuana and marijuana concentrates (32.1 pounds), 1,392 grams of methamphetamine (3.1 pounds), and 149 grams of cocaine (about a third of a pound). 
Opioids do show up in the area but almost exclusively as illegally obtained prescription pills and fentanyl patches. 
Roughly half of the 1,454 prescription pills obtained by the task force were opioids with most of the rest being the anti-anxiety drug Xanax and the ADHD-drug Adderall. The number of prescription pills seized or purchased rose by more than 50 percent last year. 
One reason heroin and related opioids haven't made major inroads in the Mankato area is that the large population of young adults aren't attracted to it. 
"It's really not a college student drug," Wersal said. "They're more into the cocaine and party drugs (such as MDMA drugs commonly known as ecstasy and molly)." 
The purchase and seizure of traditional marijuana (nearly 30 pounds) was up more than 57 percent, and the amount of marijuana concentrate — oil, wax and marijuana edibles — nearly doubled. Much of that, including popular THC-infused Gummy Bear knock-offs, came from Colorado and other states where the products are legal, he said. 
The amount of meth obtained was up 77 percent, and Wersal said that drug continues to be the most destructive in south-central Minnesota in undermining the health of users, disrupting families and prompting crime by addicts desperate for money for future meth purchases. 
"Just about every crime — burglary, robbery — you can link back to drug use and a large majority of the time it's meth," he said. 
Along with the seized drugs and the arrests, the task force removed 19 children from the homes of drug-abusing or drug-selling caregivers in 2017. Forty-four firearms were seized. 
The only drug the task force saw less of last year was cocaine, and that's because 2016's number was inflated by a single case in St. James where 2 pounds of cocaine was seized. 
Just four people were charged with manufacturing illegal drugs, all of it meth from two labs. That's three more arrests than the previous year but a fraction of what was seen two decades ago when most locally consumed meth was locally produced in makeshift labs. 
New regulations that made it harder to shoplift the cold medicines used as a raw ingredient for meth production are a major reason, and it now costs about as much to cook up a homemade batch of meth as to purchase imported meth, Wersal said. It's also much more risky because possession of a small amount of meth is a misdemeanor but manufacture of the same amount carries a 86-month prison sentence. 
"But a few of the old-school people still think they can do it," he said, saying the 2017 arrests all involved older meth users. 
Of the 165 drug arrests last year by the task force, 78 resulted in charges of first-, second- or third-degree charges for possession or sale of hard drugs or possession or sale of large amounts of any type of illegal drugs. There were also 75 charges for fifth-degree drug offenses, typically misdemeanors for possession of smaller amounts of drugs. 
The people facing fifth-degree charges weren't a target of the task force, Wersal said. Those charges often involved people on hand when a search warrant or investigation resulted in the arrest of a dealer. 
"He's usually got three or four friends there who have dope in their pockets," Wersal said. "And they don't get a free ride."

title: Marijuana, bullets and stolen wallet allegedly found in North Mankato residence
story:
NORTH MANKATO â€” A felon is facing several new charges after a large amount of marijuana, bullets and a stolen wallet allegedly were found in his North Mankato residence. 
Police went to the Nicollet Avenue home of Adam Hans Sageng, 36, on Tuesday looking for a wanted man they suspected was staying there. 
They didn't find the man, but they found evidence of drug dealing and other crimes, according to a criminal complaint. 
Authorities allegedly found marijuana in several locations weighing a collective 24 ounces. They also allegedly found marijuana wax, pipes, scales and other paraphernalia, four cellphones and a box of shotgun shells, which Sageng is not permitted to possess because he has felony convictions. 
A wallet and gift cards that had been reported stolen from an employee's vehicle outside an area restaurant April 27 also allegedly were found. A co-worker of the victim told police a man came to the restaurant May 1 and tried to use a stolen gift certificate with the victim's name on it. A North Mankato police officer showed the co-worker a photograph of Sageng and the co-worker identified him as the man who brought in the gift certificate. 
Sageng was charged Thursday in Nicollet County District Court with felony and gross misdemeanor drug possession, felony possession of ammunition by a felon and misdemeanor possession of stolen property.

title: Dramatic jump in deaths due to drugs, alcohol, and suicide among Americans leave experts searching for solutions
story:
The drug, alcohol, and suicide epidemics currently are responsible for 350 deaths per day, or 14 per hour, or one every four minutes, according to the report Pain in the Nation: The Drug, Alcohol and Suicide Epidemics and the Need for a National Resilience Strategy, released by the Trust for America’s Health (TFAH) and Well Being Trust (WBT) earlier this year. Drug overdose deaths tripled from 2000 to 2015, alcohol-induced deaths increased 37 percent over that period, and suicide deaths jumped 28 percent in that duration. (File) 
OWATONNA — Despite public health efforts to educate Americans on the perils of substance abuse — as well as demystifying mental health in hopes of attenuating suicides — deaths from drugs, alcohol, and suicide continue to climb at staggering rates in the United States. 
The drug, alcohol, and suicide epidemics currently are responsible for 350 deaths per day — that’s 14 per hour, or one every four minutes — according to the report Pain in the Nation: The Drug, Alcohol and Suicide Epidemics and the Need for a National Resilience Strategy, released by the Trust for America’s Health (TFAH) and Well Being Trust (WBT) earlier this year. Drug overdose deaths tripled from 2000 to 2015, alcohol-induced deaths increased 37 percent over that period, and suicide deaths jumped 28 percent in that duration. 
“It is discouraging,” said Amy Roggenbuck, public health director for Steele and Dodge counties. “Our biggest challenge in public health is finding the people who need services the most [...] and filling in the gaps.” 
At Public Health, “we do family home visits,” because “drugs and alcohol can be a cycle within families,” Roggenbuck said. So often, children who grow up in homes with drug or alcohol abuse “don’t know any different,” and “it’s their norm.” 
“We’re trying to break that cycle and teach them healthier habits,” she added. “We can be a support system for them.” 
Drugs, alcohol, and suicide could account for 1.6 million fatalities over the coming decade (2016 to 2025), according to the Pain in the Nation report. That would represent a 60 percent leap from the previous decade, as there were a million deaths from these causes from 2006 to 2015. 
Perhaps even more alarming, the study found that those estimates for the coming decade might actually be on the conservative side due to the exponential leap in use of drugs like heroin, fentanyl, and carfentanil. If that trajectory continues, death rates would actually double, to 2 million, by 2025. 
“In almost every meeting I’ve been in over the past year, the opioid crisis comes up,” Roggenbuck said. 
Even the local area has seen recent deaths from fentanyl and carfentanil, in which victims unwittingly ingested it when it was mixed in with their usual drug of choice. 
All that said, while “opioids are getting most of the attention, alcohol is still our number one drug of choice,” she said. “It still tops all the others.” 
As of 2015, more than 43 million Americans experienced a mental health issue, more than 20 million had a substance use disorder, and more than 8 million experienced both. 
As high as those numbers are, they are almost assuredly conservative, due to the stigma around mental health and substance abuse, as well as a paucity of available treatment options, according to Pain in the Nation. Only about 10 percent of people with substance use issues receive the recommended treatments. 
In 2017, 60 percent of residents taken in by Safe Harbour — a community-based intensive residential treatment program under the South Central Human Relations Center umbrella — presented with dual diagnosis, i.e., mental health struggles and a substance abuse disorder, said Amy Bartz, treatment director for intensive residential services. Fortunately, in the past handful of years, more organizations have recognized the proliferation of dual diagnosis, leading to combining efforts, rather than “a silo of services.” 
Unfortunately, just as “there’s no one-size-fits-all treatment for people” battling addiction, there’s not “one root cause,” either, said Barb Durbahn, director of community programs for SCHRC. However, people do usually turn to drugs or alcohol to in hopes of attenuating some physical or emotional pain. 
While one can argue whether the world is any more stressful now than ever before, there is more of an emphasis on “quick relief” in American society, Bartz said. Rather than “leaning into pain” with the support of family and friends, individuals too often isolate themselves and reach for drugs or alcohol to ameliorate their problems. 
Despite social media’s inherent promise of uniting people, folks are as lonely as ever before, according to recent research. 
For example, in an online survey of more than 20,000 Americans conducted by Cigna earlier this year, 47 percent said they feel left out, 43 percent feel their relationships are not meaningful, 43 percent feel isolated from others, and one-in-five surveyed said they rarely or never feel close to people. The most-socially-isolated age group in the report was those 18-22, and young people with the highest rates of social media use felt no less lonely than individuals with very limited social media involvement. 
Suicide rates among teenagers continue to soar, up an incredible 70 percent from 2006 to 2016, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Suicides per 100,000 teens between the ages of 10 and 17 jumped from 2.97 in 2006 to 5.05 in 2016. 
Admissions for those ages 5-17 for suicidal thoughts and actions more than doubled from 2008-2015, according to a study of pediatric hospitals released in May of 2017. White males between the ages of 14 and 21 were the group at the highest risk of suicide. 
“I do think people are taking suicidal threats more seriously,” which may account for part of that uptick in hospital visits, Roggenbuck said. However, the number of individuals — especially young people — committing suicide or at least contemplating ending their lives is obviously disconcerting. 
“Just anecdotally, I think more bullying goes on — even though schools have addressed it well — because of social media, which makes it easier to cyber-bully,” Roggenbuck said. “You see it in the news all the time.” 
“I also feel there is more pressure on kids,” now, than even a decade ago, she added. “Kids deal with adult issues at a younger age.” 
Furthermore, drugs on the street have become both stronger and easier to procure in recent years, Durbahn said. “Those of us in the field are becoming aware of how easy it is to get addicted.” 
“These are people who didn’t plan to become addicted,” she added. “This was not their plan, but recreational use (shifted) to addiction pretty quickly, and then it is tough.” 
Drugs and alcohol, of course, can lead into suicidal behavior, Roggenbuck said. “People are self-medicating, but it’s not helping their depression, it’s making it worse.” 
More Americans actually die from suicide each year than from car accidents or opioids, according to the CDC. Suicide and “self-harm,” which includes suicide attempts, cost the nation $70 billion annually in medical care and lost work time. 
Public Health, of course, is “on the preventative side,” Roggenbuck said. “We’re upstream, trying to figure out the root causes.” 
On the issue of suicide, Crisis Response for Southeast Minnesota “has been a great resource,” and “they’re maybe underutilized,” she said. Anyone can call the 24/7 help line — because, naturally, people don’t tend to schedule their personal crises during regular business hours — at 844-274-7472, and staff will gather information, ensure safety, and connect callers with local resources. 
Additionally, as of April 1, Minnesota joined the national nonprofit Crisis Text Line, which is available every day of the year at any time. People who text “MN” to the number 741741 will be connected with a trained counselor. 
Furthermore, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is available at 1-800-273-TALK (8255) and provides free, confidential support year-round for people in crisis. The service includes options for veterans and current military members. 
Preventing suicide is paramount, since so many individuals who live through attempted suicide are glad they failed, Bartz said. Of those she’s spoken to during screenings at Safe Harbour, “the vast majority are grateful they didn’t succeed (at suicide).” 
On a micro level, Steele County ranked 31st of 87 Minnesota counties in the health outcomes category in the latest edition of the Robert Wood Johnson and University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute annual County Health Rankings. In the length of life category, Steele County ranked 25th. 
The Health Factors category examined everything from health behaviors (Steele County came in 29th) to physical environment (85th of 87 counties). In overall quality of life, Steele County ranked 47th in 2018. 
Steele County was once a stalwart at the top of the county health rankings, but has declined in recent years. In 2012, Steele County was the report’s healthiest county in Minnesota. 
Roggenbuck doesn’t put nearly as much stock in these rankings as she does in the community health survey residents of Steele County take every five years or the one given by Allina Health every three years. 
Despite the fall of Steele County in the County Health Rankings, “I don’t think we’ve gone down the drain,” she said. And, lest anyone think she’s just defending her county, Dodge County — also under her purview — finished fourth this year, and “I don’t take that very seriously, either.” 
She also closely examines data from the Minnesota Student Survey, which is “pretty telling,” she said. Since 90 percent of Americans with a substance abuse problem started smoking, drinking, or using other drugs before age 18, it’s instructive to see how many Steele County youth have already been introduced to those substances. 
In Steele County in 2016, 10 percent of eighth-graders reported drinking an alcoholic beverage at least once in the past month, while the state average among eighth graders was under 8 percent, according to the Steele County Safe and Drug Free Coalition. However, fewer Steele County high school freshmen and juniors were drinking than the state average in 2016, with 9 percent of local freshmen and 24 percent of local juniors reporting imbibing in a given month against 11 percent and 25 percent, respectively, for state averages. 
Fewer Steele County teens and adolescents were abusing prescription medications or using marijuana in a 30-day snapshot than the state average, according to the coalition. Only 7 percent of Steele County youth in grades 8, 9, and 11 were using marijuana — that number was 9 percent for the state average — and only 3 percent of Steele County students in those aforementioned grades reported abusing prescription drugs, contrasted with a state average of 5 percent. 
The Coalition is also working with the Statewide Health Improvement Partnership (SHIP) to reduce the availability of drugs and prescription opioids by enhancing access to safe storage and disposal methods; the goal is to increase the amount of those pills collected by 10 percent by next October, according to Mary Urch, Steele County Public Health nurse. Furthermore, a second prong of the strategy is to provide information to parents to prevent access to prescription drugs/opioids by their children, increase understanding of epidemic trends, and remind everyone of the risks involved. 
In order to stem the tide of deaths from drugs, alcohol, and suicide, “we need to get to kids early and don’t just tell them what to do, but show them how to be healthy in their daily lives,” Roggenbuck said. “We also need to make sure people know there is support out there, because there’s still a lot of stigma attached” to seeking help. 
Reach Reporter Ryan Anderson at 507-444-2376 or follow him on Twitter @randerson_ryan.

title: Marijuana enters party platform
story:
The Independence Party of Minnesota has come out in favor of marijuana legalization, joining an emerging group of smaller political parties to do so. 
But the IP is the first major party in the state to take a definitive pro-legalization stance, another sign that social perceptions of the federally outlawed plant are changing. 
“I think eventually it’s going to be legalized in all 50 states cause there’s so much revenue that the state can pick up,” said Thomas Price, an IP-endorsed candidate for the state House of Representatives District 27A. 
That district includes Blooming Prairie and has a DFL incumbent in Rep. Shannon Savick. 
Price favors legalization of marijuana, as well as the expansion of medical programs. He pointed to high tax revenues in Colorado from legalized recreational use and said that current limitations create a “road block” between cannabis and the people who could potentially benefit from it. 
In legislative debates, some Minnesota lawmakers used the same Colorado policy as a cautionary slippery slope argument against medical programs. 
The IP has fielded candidates in multiple state and national races this year. They include Brandon Borgos, who is seeking the Attorney General spot. He sits on the board of Minnesota NORML, a marijuana legalization lobbying group. 
Hannah Nicollet, who is running on the IP ticket for governor, also has spoken in favor of legalization. 
To remain a major party in Minnesota, an IP candidate must receive at least 5 percent of the vote in a statewide race. Independence Party Chairman Mark Jenkins has said that the party is more than just its marijuana stance, and that taking sides on some issues was the right decision. 
Still, it is unclear if the pro-legalization position will overshadow other issues and whether voters will be attracted to or alienated by the party as a result. 
“I don’t see it as an issue that moves a lot of votes one way or another,” said Tim Penny, former U.S. Representative who also ran for governor in 2002 as an IP candidate. 
Penny now heads the Southern Minnesota Initiative Foundation in Owatonna. He said that he isn’t as active in the IP as he used to be, but said that there is a “core of party activists” in the region. 
He said that while the pro-legalization stance distinguishes the party from Democrats and Republicans, it may not be a net gain in support — in St. Paul or in Washington, D.C. Party leaders might be better off focusing on what he called more relevant issues like fiscal policy, government reform and campaign finance. 
In the end, he’s confident that at least one IP candidate will capture 5 percent of the statewide vote and retain major party status in Minnesota. 
Public views on marijuana have shifted over the past decade. Penny said he was surprised when he first heard of medical cannabis proposals during his gubernatorial run. This spring, Minnesota became the 22nd state to implement medical marijuana, though it is one of the strictest policies yet. 
Legalization models in Washington and Colorado are being closely watched by opponents and proponents alike, with the former worried about increased access. 
Darren Reed, project coordinator for the Steele County Safe and Drug-Free Coalition, said that whatever the legal status of a substance, the potential for abuse remains. He argued that loosening marijuana laws increases that risk. 
“It’s a scary thought for me, because I think any time we’re putting a drug into more people’s hands there is a danger to it,” Reed said. 
He believes that the changing social attitudes toward marijuana create a false sense of safety. And while he promotes moderation with a legal substance like alcohol, Reed doesn’t anticipate advocating safe use of marijuana over prohibition. 
In this election year, the marijuana movement is making a presence. In the races for Minnesota governor, auditor and attorney general, candidates have filed under pro-cannabis party affiliations such as Legal Marijuana Now and Grassroots-Legalize Cannabis. 
Early in Price’s campaign for state House, he said the issue hasn’t come to the forefront of discussion yet. But he feels he’s on the right side of a growing special interest. 
“Change is inevitable,” he said. 
MPR News contributed to this story. Minnesota Public Radio News can be heard in Owatonna on 103.9 FM or online at MPRnews.org. Reach reporter Matt Hudson at 507-444-2372. Follow him on Twitter @OPPMattH

title: Two charged with more than 30 pounds of pot
story:
It might be legal back home in Colorado, but the 30-plus pounds of marijuana and marijuana wax police reportedly found during a traffic stop Saturday has landed two men in hot water with Steele County prosecutors. 
Justin Mourray, 29, and Jesse Price II, 32, both of Colorado, were charged Monday with third-degree possession of more than 10 kilograms of marijuana, which carries a maximum statutory penalty of 20 years imprisonment or a $250,000 fine. 
According to the complaint, two Minnesota State Patrol troopers parked on Interstate 35 south of Owatonna spotted a car with an object dangling from its rear-view mirror at about 6 p.m. and initiated a traffic stop. The vehicle, which had partially obscured Colorado plates, was driven by Mourray, with Price in the passenger seat. 
The troopers reported a strong smell of marijuana, and a K-9 unit alerted to several points on the car. Both occupants initially declined to exit, and eventually stepped out and were placed in the back of a squad vehicle. Price reportedly told police they needed a warrant to search the vehicle, and continued locking the car with his key fob from the squad vehicle as troopers attempted to search it. 
In the car, the troopers reportedly found several dozen plastic bags and containers of marijuana, numerous mason jars containing marijuana wax, and marijuana debris and other paraphernalia scattered around the interior of the vehicle. 
By weight, police found 27 pounds of raw marijuana, and 7 pounds of marijuana wax. 
The complaint does not specify why the troopers were both parked at the same interstate crossover when the alleged drug couriers passed by. 
Court records show both men made initial court appearances Monday. Price was bail of $5,000 with conditions or $25,000 without and is set for another hearing March 30, while Mourray’s bail was set at $5,000 and $20,000 and no hearings are scheduled until a settlement conference in May. 
William Morris is a reporter for the Owatonna People’s Press. He can be reached at 444-2372; follow him on Twitter @OPPWilliam 
Price 
Mourray 
City government and public safety reporter for the Owatonna People's Press

title: Final Owatonna man sentenced for synthetic marijuana sale
story:
An Owatonna man who admitted to possessing synthetic marijuana that he then sold to an undercover cop at an Owatonna tobacco shop told the judge during his sentencing hearing Monday that he was a “good guy.” 
Omar Ahmed Abdallah, 48, appeared in Steele County District Court Monday afternoon for sentencing on a charge of possessing and selling synthetic marijuana to an agent with the South Central Drug Task Force in March of 2013. Abdallah, who originally was charged with three felonies and a misdemeanor, faced up to 15 years in prison and a $100,000 fine for the most serious of the charges. 
He pleaded guilty to a single felony charge in June and will perform 580 hours of community service and pay $581 in combined fines and court fees. 
“I apologize for what I did,” Abdallah told Judge Joseph Bueltel through an interpreter. “I have been here 20 years and haven’t had any trouble. I never drink, I never smoke, and I’m a good guy. I am sorry.” 
It was his lack of any prior drug-related offenses that likely kept him from serving any time behind bars, said Assistant County Attorney Sasha Zekoff, who noted that pre-sentence investigation recommended community service for Abdallah. And, indeed, a search of Minnesota court records shows that the majority of Abdallah’s run-ins with the law have been for minor traffic violations. In 2008, he was charged with selling tobacco to a minor, a misdemeanor. 
It was a point that was not lost on Ben Cass, Abdallah’s attorney. 
“The long and short of it, Mr. Abdallah, in selling the products at the store, believed what he was selling was legal,” Cass told the judge. “...Mr. Omar Abdallah regrets what has happened ... He has no prior history of controlled substance offenses.” 
Judge Bueltel gave Abdallah two years to complete the community service. 
Abdallah’s arrest came following a nearly year-long investigation of a local tobacco business — what was then known as Jericho Tobacco. During the investigation, members of the drug task force found what they said was $150,000 worth of synthetic marijuana. 
Three men — Omar Abdallah, Khamis Abdallah and Wael Abdallah — were all charged in March 2013 with crimes related to the possession and sale of the synthetic drug. 
Khamis Abdallah, who was in court Monday to show support for his brother, pleaded guilty last November to possession of synthetic cannabinoid, a felony. Two other felony charges were dropped as a part of the plea agreement. 
He was sentenced to 90 days, though all but three days of his sentence were stayed for a year and he received credit for time served. He was put on unsupervised probation and ordered to pay $381 in fines and court fees. 
Wael Abdallah, the only one of the three men who was not charged with a felony in the case, pleaded guilty to a possession charge in March 2013, about a week after the charges were filed against the three men. Like Khamis Abdallah, he got credit for three days he served in jail, was placed on unsupervised probation for a year and ordered to pay $381 in fines and court fees. 
Jericho Tobacco has since changed ownership and its name. 
Reach Managing Editor Jeffrey Jackson at 444-2371, or follow him on Twitter.com @OPPJeffrey 
Abdallah 
Jeffrey Jackson is the managing editor of the Owatonna People's Press. He can be reached at 507-444-2371 or via email at jjackson@owatonna.com

title: Two Minnesota men arrested on felony drug charges in Steele County
story:
Two Minnesota men were charged with felony drug possession on Friday after they allegedly transported marijuana from California to Minnesota in a rental car. 
Jason Ashley Kingsley, 34, of St. Paul and Todd Richard Libby, 38, of Osseo were both charged with third degree possession of a controlled substance, which requires suspects be in possession of at least 10 kilograms of marijuana. The crime carries a penalty of at least two years in jail, and as many as 30 years, along with a fine of $250,000. 
According to a Minnesota State Patrol criminal complaint, the Northwest Metro Drug Task Force was patrolling the Minnesota and Iowa border based on information from an informant that Libby was using a rental vehicle to transport large quantities of marijuana from California to Minnesota. The task force was working with local and state officers to enforce any traffic stop because members of the task force were in unmarked vehicles. 
At about 11:30 p.m. Wednesday, an officer observed a red four-door sedan traveling north on Interstate 35. According to the complaint, one of the occupants in the vehicle matched Libby’s description and the vehicle had a California license plate. The vehicle was a Ford Taurus registered to Libby from Avis, according to the complaint. 
The officer observed the car was traveling at about 75 mph and was crossing over the fog line, according to the complaint. The state patrol had set up a staging area to execute a stop at the intersection of I-35 and Highway 30 near Ellendale. 
The state patrol trooper pulled the vehicle over near the northbound Straight River Rest Area. Upon making contact with the occupants of the vehicle, the trooper identified Kinglsey as the driver and Libby as the passenger, according to the complaint. Kinglsey was reportedly “extremely nervous and could not sit still.” 
According to the report, the trooper saw energy drinks, a single key in the ignition, multiple cell phones and little luggage in the rear seat. When the trooper went back to his squad car, he requested a canine unit to respond to the scene. 
The trooper returned to the vehicle and asked Kinglsey to get out of the car. Kingsley said he and Libby were traveling back from California, where they had been for two weeks on a business trip in Napa Valley for Libby’s wine store, according to the complaint. 
Before placing Kingsley in the back of his squad car, the trooper asked him where they had started driving from that day, to which Kingsley replied Grand Junction, Colo. 
The trooper then spoke to Libby, who said they had left from Denver. According to the complaint, Grand Junction and Denver are about 243 miles apart. The trooper asked Libby about the lack of luggage in the vehicle, and Libby said it was in the trunk. 
The canine unit arrived and immediately alerted the officers to the presence of drugs in the vehicle. Officer’s searched the trunk and found three suit cases and one duffel bag, according to the complaint. 
The duffel bag contained only clothing, but the suitcases contained a total of 17 bags that were vacuum-sealed. Inside the bags was a substance that tested positive as marijuana. The bags were 1.4 pounds each, containing 10.7 kilograms, or 23.58 pounds, of marijuana. 
The car was towed to Dean’s in Owatonna, where a more thorough search was conducted. During the search, authorities found $1,081 in cash, two iPhones and two Samsung flip phones. 
Both men have had previous drug conviction charges according to the complaint. On Friday, both men had their conditional bail set at $20,000 and were ordered to submit to testing if requested by a peace officer. They are next due in court on Dec. 13. 
Reach reporter Al Strain at 444-2376 or follow him on Twitter.com@OPPalstrain 
Reach reporter Al Strain at 444-2376 or follow him on Twitter.com@OPPalstrain 
KINGSLEY 
LIBBY 
I am a reporter for the Owatonna People's Press covering cops, courts, the city beat, business, agriculture and features. I  graduated from Wartburg College in Waverly, Iowa in May of 2012. While in college I majored in Communication Arts with an emphasis

title: Eye in the sky: police show new drone to city council
story:
Detective Joel Hunt, right, demonstrates some of the capability’s of the police department’s new unmanned drone before Tuesday’s City Council meeting. (William Morris/People’s Press) 
OWATONNA — City Council members were disappointed to learn they would not see a flight demonstration in the council chambers before Tuesday’s meeting. Detective Joel Hunt, however, held firm. 
“That would be against everything I learned in my FAA training,” he said. “That would be machismo.” 
Hunt is the police department point person on the new unmanned aerial drone system purchased by the city. And while he declined to fly it during Tuesday’s study session, he was still able to explain and demonstrate many of the new capabilities the drone brings to the police department, and to the city as a whole. 
The drone is a DJI Matrice 210, a heavy-duty drone designed with sophisticated public safety and engineering uses in mind. Between the drone, the batteries and controllers, and four different camera options, the city has spent almost $40,000 to get the project up and running, money Hunt said came largely from found property money or civil asset forfeitures. 
Several city departments in recent years have looked into drone technology, efforts that came together under the police department, Hunt said. 
“Engineering was also looking at purchasing a drone, they’re looking at a consumer grade drone, and once we started to look into different applications ... when you look at the amount of money you’re spending on a consumer-level drone, and then when you can use it, that’s the difference,” he said. 
Currently two officers, Hunt and Sgt. Jason Petterson, are trained to operate the drone. Hunt said the department is still working on its policies and standard operating procedures, but describes a wide range of possible uses for the drone, ranging from maintaining a perimeter around a building to searching for missing children to even autonomously following a suspect. 
“You can point your camera at a certain person and it will tab them, and then it’s going to lock onto that person and follow them, and depending on what different modes you have for obstacle avoidance, it’ll move around different things,” he said. 
Capt. Eric Rethemeier said drones in recent years have become much more affordable, giving smaller departments the chance to add aerial surveillance to their toolboxes. 
“I came from a police department [Cedar Rapids, Iowa,] that had an air wing,” he said. “Very useful, we used it all the time, really expensive. Quite often, the aerial wing we had responded faster than we could on the street, so we always had that air coverage.” 
The drone comes with certain restrictions, some laid down by the Federal Aviation Administration and some by federal court rulings. The drone has a theoretical range of 7 km, including up to 2.8 km above ground, but in practice must remain in line-of-sight to the operator. Department policy will forbid the drone to be weaponized. And operators must observe the same restrictions on searches and seizures as other forms of policing. 
“There are privacy concerns. I can’t just fly this over someone’s house with the [heat-sensing camera] and say, ‘Oh, there’s a lot of heat kicking out of this house, m. Maybe there’s a marijuana grow in there,’ unless I have a warrant for that,” Hunt said, adding that yards not visible from the street are usually safe from scrutiny. “With a drone, flying at 400 feet, I think it’s probably a grey area that courts haven’t exactly decided with new technology, but we’re always going to err on the side of caution unless it’s plain view that we can see.” 
The drone already has been deployed once, to help the Sheriff’s Office seek a juvenile suspect who had fled through woods and onto a thinly-frozen river. In the future, it will be available through mutual aid agreements to other local government agencies. 
And it’s not just the police who envision having a use for the drone. Hunt said the engineering, community development and parks department have all pitched in money for the project, and could put the drone to work on projects ranging from surveying pavement conditions on city streets to shooting promotional videos for city recreation activities to monitoring grass and structure fires. 
“You could probably pay a subcontractor a lot of money to do that, or we could do it ourselves,” Hunt said. 
William Morris is a reporter for the Owatonna People’s Press. He can be reached at 444-2372; follow him on Twitter @OPPWilliam 
City government and public safety reporter for the Owatonna People's Press

title: Several charged after weekend brawl at the Blast
story:
An Owatonna man is charged with felony assault and threats after a melee involving baseball bats and a pellet gun broke out Saturday at an ice cream shop downtown. 
Police say at least half a dozen people, many juveniles, were involved in the incident Saturday at Blast Softserve on Rose Street, and Jarod Fuller, 18, was charged Tuesday with second-degree assault, terroristic threats, and misdemeanor obstruction and possession of drug paraphernalia. He could face between one and seven years imprisonment if convicted on the assault charge. 
Also facing misdemeanor assault and disorderly conduct charges over the incident are 19-year-old Bryan Dupris and a 17-year-old male, police say. 
According to the complaint against Fuller, police were called Saturday to the fight in progress with a baseball bat, and spoke to several people found fleeing the scene. Several of the juveniles told officers that Fuller and the 17-year-old male were planning to fight, originally at Dartt’s Park, but then gathered at the ice cream shop instead, where Dupris and the teen instead began fighting. At some point, Fuller reportedly pulled out a realistic-looking handgun and Dupris a knife, and witnesses report hearing Fuller threatening others present. 
Several participants in the fight reportedly told police they’d been struck by a bottle or a baseball bat, with one bleeding from the head, and police found a possibly blood-stained bat on the scene. Dupris told police he saw Fuller bring the handgun to the fight, and that he took it from Fuller and threw it away after crossing the nearby bridge. 
An officer on patrol spotted Fuller on Sunday and arrested him, during which he reportedly struggled and yanked at the cuffs, scraping the officer, and also reportedly made statements such as “I kill cops.” Police found a butterfly knife in Fuller’s pocket, and in his backpack found a pipe with apparent marijuana residue, packaging and instructions for a BB air pistol and spare CO2 canisters, a stun gun and a notebook with statements about shooting and injuring unspecified people. 
Owatonna Police Capt. Jeff Mundale said investigators do not know what was the cause behind the fight, and said police have not located the handgun used, which they believe is a BB gun consistent with the evidence found on Fuller. 
Court records show Fuller has had several past brushes with the law as a juvenile, including one case where he was charged with shooting out a neighbor’s windows and firing at passing cars with another BB gun. In the newest case, court records show Fuller appeared in court Tuesday and was set bail of $10,000 with conditions or $20,000 without. His next hearing is set for April 12. 
William Morris is a reporter for the Owatonna People’s Press. He can be reached at 444-2372; follow him on Twitter @OPPWilliam 
Fuller 
City government and public safety reporter for the Owatonna People's Press
