title: Laramie County state House candidates debate in forum
story:
Martinez during House District 44’s public forum, hosted by the League of Women Voters, on Tuesday, July 10, 2018, at Cheyenne City Council Chambers at City Hall in Cheyenne. Jacob Byk/Wyoming Tribune Eagle 
CHEYENNE – Candidates for three of Laramie County’s state House districts disagreed about issues such as alternatives to incarceration and economic diversification and discussed a number of other issues at a forum hosted by the League of Women Voters on Tuesday night at Cheyenne City Council Chambers at City Hall. 
Candidates attended from House District 10, which covers much of Laramie County east of Cheyenne and a sliver of eastern Goshen County; House District 12, which is located in the southwest corner of Laramie County; and House District 44, which primarily covers the downtown Cheyenne area, south of Pershing Boulevard and north of Interstate 80. 
Marguerite Herman, a League of Women Voters of Cheyenne member, moderated one panel for each race and asked similar questions on a variety of topics. All of the candidates had 90 seconds to answer each question, as well as 30 seconds to respond to their opponents. 
House District 10 
All three candidates vying for the House District 10 seat attended the forum. 
Incumbent Rep. John Eklund, a Republican, said he decided to run again because he had “unfinished business,” including bringing a skilled nursing center for veterans to the state and updating a Wyoming Department of Transportation database that keeps track of licensing information. 
Republican challenger Donn Edmunds said he wanted to do more to bring and keep young people in the state, and Democratic challenger Jenefer Pasqua said she’d focus on education funding and quality. 
While all three candidates said they support local control of money allocated for schools, Eklund and Pasqua debated on how much should be spent in that arena. 
Pasqua emphasized the need for “fully funding” education, meaning that she advocated for allocating the full amount of money calculated for each district using a formula based on student populations, property taxes and other measures – something that hasn’t always happened in the past. 
But Eklund said while there is a constitutional obligation to fund education, Wyoming already receives a high amount of per-pupil spending compared to other states. 
“There are few states that fund education as high as Wyoming,” he said. “There is a lot of question as to whether it is fully funded or whether it was (previously) overfunded.” 
The three candidates also disagreed on the state’s role in building prisons and paying for alternative programs for people convicted of crimes, such as substance abuse or mental health treatment. 
Edmunds said the state prison system already has many options for people who are incarcerated. 
“Most people who go to prison, it’s like going to college” because the people have so much time to read and exercise, he said. 
Eklund largely agreed, saying the state routinely has one of the lowest recidivism rates in the country. 
“Whatever we’re doing in our prison system is pretty good,” he said. 
He also said he didn’t think it was the Legislature’s job to determine whether somebody should qualify for alternatives to incarceration, such as community treatment. 
But Pasqua said the state needed to do more for people suffering from mental illness. 
“The main reason (mental illness) goes untreated is because there aren’t resources to pay for treatment,” she said. 
Pasqua said the state should spend more money on mental health treatment programs both in prisons and statewide. 
House District 12 
Republican Connie Czarnecki was the only candidate to physically appear at the forum, but a longtime friend of Republican candidate Clarence Styvar, Jana Ginten, appeared on his behalf. And Pasqua read a short statement for Democrat Ryan Lindsey. 
In the statement, Lindsey pledged to “focus on things that bring us together” as a state. 
Both of the men weren’t able to make it due to work obligations. 
When asked about education funding, Ginten cited Styvar’s involvement in improving education for children with disabilities. 
Ginten said that although Wyoming spends a lot for each student compared to other states, “we have very little to show for it as far as academic achievement.” 
She said Styvar would advocate for more accountability in school spending. 
But Czarnecki said she thought schools were generally fiscally responsible and there needed to be trust-building between the Legislature and local districts. 
“The local school boards know exactly what they need,” she said. “Most people on the boards are fiscally responsible, at least in my experience.” 
The candidates also differed on whether to tax tobacco in an effort to deter people from smoking. 
Czarnecki said as a surgical assistant and former smoker, she has seen the negative effects of smoking. 
“I would be in favor of a tax if it would deter anyone from smoking,” she said. 
Styvar’s answer was simple. 
“No new taxes,” Ginten said. 
House District 44 
Republican Paul Johnson was unable to attend the forum due to work obligations, but a statement was read on his behalf. 
In it, he talked about his top priorities for the state, including figuring out a solution to a “boom and bust” economy, attracting alternative health insurance options and “keeping dollars in the classroom” instead of cutting education. 
Democrat Sara Burlingame and Republican John Romero-Martinez both attended. They found a few points of agreement, including favoring the legalization of medical marijuana and promoting certain aspects of criminal justice reform. 
Both also agreed the state needed to take steps to bolster the technology sector. 
Romero-Martinez didn’t share many specifics on that point, but said in the past Wyoming had missed out on opportunities to break into the industry. 
But Burlingame cited her involvement in a tech jobs tour that brought prospective employers to the state to talk to tech-minded individuals in Wyoming. 
“It was really energizing to be a part of this,” she said. “We can position ourselves as tech innovation leaders.” 
Burlingame said she wanted to give young people more opportunities to thrive. 
She said part of that would be making sure there is equity in education – ensuring that low-income students are well-cared for. Overall, she said Wyoming’s public schools are “top notch.” 
Romero-Martinez focused on civil rights in schools and in the broader public. He said the state should especially focus on the rights of “unborn children,” religious groups and other protected classes. 
Katie Kull is the Wyoming Tribune Eagle’s criminal justice reporter. She can be reached at kkull@wyomingnews.com or 307-633-3122. Follow her on Twitter at @katiekull1.

title: Wyoming House makes last-minute changes to “stand your ground” bill
story:
Cheyenne, visits with Sen. Drew Perkins, R-Casper, during the 64th Wyoming Legislature's budget session on Thursday, March 8, 2018, at the Jonah Business Center in Cheyenne. Blaine McCartney/Wyoming Tribune Eagle 
CHEYENNE – Last-minute changes came to a so-called “stand your ground” bill in the Wyoming House of Representatives, while another similar bill remains in flux in the Senate. 
While the concept of “stand your ground” has largely enjoyed the support of lawmakers in the Wyoming Legislature, it hasn’t been smooth sailing for the bills. House Bill 168 easily made it through its chamber of origin. But Senate File 71 went through a back-and-forth of amendments before moving to the House. 
The bill’s proponents – including its sponsor, Sen. Anthony Bouchard, R-Cheyenne – were concerned senators posing complex legal questions about immunity provisions in the original bill gutted SF 71 with amendments. On third and final reading in the Senate, the bill was amended to include provisions that shooters needed to hold an “honest” belief their safety was threatened, whether “real or apparent.” Another amendment also added protection for those who threaten use of deadly force to diffuse potential deadly outcomes. 
During the Senate Agriculture Committee meeting Tuesday evening, lawmakers amended the House bill to mirror the amended Senate version. Both bills passed their respective chamber’s committees that day. 
But on Friday, SF 71 came to the floor for its third and final reading. Rep. Mike Gierau, R-Jackson, brought an amendment to make it so civil immunity would not apply if a person engaged in the use of defensive force “recklessly injures or kills another whom the person did not intend to use the reasonable defensive force against.” 
Debate ensued, with lawmakers arguing a broad swath of reasons. Some questioned whether existing statute would already not allow for civil immunity in such a circumstance. Bo Biteman, R-Ranchester, said the amendment’s sponsor was trying to “kill a bill (he) doesn’t like.” The House bill’s sponsor, Rep. Tim Salazar, R-Dubois, agreed with Biteman. 
Gierau made it clear he did not support the bill when he made the amendment, but wanted to make it more palatable assuming it would pass. 
The amendment was adopted by a voice vote, and the bill passed the House 51-9 on its final reading. In order to make its way to the governor’s desk, SF 71 would need to go back to the Senate for a vote on concurrence. 
On Friday, the Senate laid back HB 168, meaning the chamber could vote on it when it convenes today. 
Marijuana reform dies again 
The Wyoming Legislature has once again failed to pass marijuana law reforms. 
Senators passed their marijuana reform bill last week, which follows the House killing its version of the bill in the Legislature’s first week. 
The Joint Judiciary Committee passed two bills during the interim, one for each chamber, attempting to reform marijuana laws to address several concerns put forth by law enforcement and the courts. Products infused with cannabis, such as edibles and liquids, continue to vex policymakers in terms of what amounts constitute felonies. 
Senate File 23 seemed viable until the House did not consider it for the Committee of the Whole, killing the legislation Wednesday. 
Sen. Tara Nethercott, R-Cheyenne, a member of the Judiciary Committee, said it’s frustrating to see it fail again. But the complexity of the matter has made moving the policies forward a challenge for a body of lawmakers somewhere between favoring legalization and further criminalization. 
Despite the apparent impasse, Nethercott said she’s confident the needle is being moved closer to codifying marijuana reform. 
“With more time comes a greater understanding of how these products are affecting people and what appropriate regulation is,” she said. 
On the other hand, Rep. Charles Pelkey, D-Laramie, said he hasn’t seen “an inch of progress.” 
“It’s time to concede that we are at an impasse, with the House staking out a more moderate position,” he said in an email. “Let’s stop wasting time until we get some new folks in both bodies.” 
All blockchain bills move forward 
Wyoming is now set up statutorily to become a national and world leader in the blockchain sector, if the legislative measures’ proponents are correct. 
All five bills related to blockchain technology – House Bill 19, House Bill 70, House Bill 101, House Bill 126 and Senate File 111 – made their way through the Wyoming Legislature during the 2018 session. All await the governor’s signature except HB 19, which was signed earlier this week. 
Blockchain is essentially a digital ledger for storing information, including cryptocurrency. Crypto-currencies – the most commonly known is bitcoin – are essentially money. Many have touted Wyoming as an ideal place for the blockchain sector to flourish. Given Wyoming’s need for economic diversification going forward, state lawmakers have gone all-in on making sure statutes can foster the sector. 
One of the Legislature’s leading proponents of the bills, Rep. Tyler Lindholm, R-Sundance, said Friday the push has been a success. While there’s a chance nefarious entities will try to take advantage of Wyoming’s statutes, he said he’s confident the secretary of state’s office has the tools it needs to address concerns. But as with any legislation, Lindholm said there can always be “unintended consequences.” 
“We don’t know where this is going to go or how it’s going to happen, but Wyoming is going to lead the way in the U.S. and the world,” he said. “That’s fascinating and really exciting.” 
CHEYENNE – Wyoming Gov. Matt Mead did not release any information about legislative measures he vetoed before press time Wednesday. 
Joel Funk is the Wyoming Tribune Eagle’s state government reporter. He can be reached at jfunk@wyomingnews.com or 307-633-3124. Follow him on Twitter at @jmacfunk.

title: Drug suspect disputes chase details
story:
Casey Hardison, the supposed drug dealer who police chased through town last week, is challenging almost every detail of the investigation. 
Hardison is wanted in Teton County on charges of delivery of marijuana and aggravated assault and battery after he allegedly sold pot to an undercover cop last week and then took off, resulting in a high-speed chase through Jackson. 
“After the handover with Mikey, a white truck stopped like he didn’t know where he was going,” Hardison told the News&Guide in a telephone interview from an undisclosed location. “The white truck tried to box me in. Then I saw two guys. I just threw it into gear and punched it.” 
Agents with the Wyoming Division of Criminal Investigations had been planning the sting for over a year, according to documents, and said it was the result of several undercover drug deals with Hardison. 
But the attempted arrest left Hardison with $6,000 of government cash and cops with 2 pounds of marijuana. 
Police say Hardison almost ran them over when he realized he was about to be arrested. 
“Special agents jumped from the path of Hardison’s vehicle to avoid being struck,” court records state. 
But Hardison said he took off because he thought he was being robbed. 
“They were in unmarked cars and plain clothes,” Hardison said. “They displayed no insignia and were wearing none. At that point in time I had the right to protect my safety.” 
Hardison disputes most details of the probable cause affidavit, in which police shared details in order to get a judge’s signature on the arrest warrant. 
“As far as the officers approaching, there was no possible way for them to come to harm,” Hardison said. “It’s exaggerated and inaccurate. I had no intention of such thing. I was fleeing a scene where I was possibly being attacked by unknown intruders.” 
Police said they chased Hardison for a short time through Jackson but eventually stopped because of safety reasons. 
“As Hardison sped away a brief pursuit was conducted by law enforcement vehicles displaying emergency lights and sirens,” documents state. “Based on Hardison’s actions while driving, high speeds, numerous turns down streets and obvious disregard for the safety of the public, law enforcement ended any further attempts to stop Hardison’s vehicle.” 
But Hardison said he got away and police continued to search for him. 
“There were no lights,” Hardison said. “I pulled away and made the next right turn and next right turn. They pursued me all the way across South Park. They claimed they stopped for safety. I hooked into this little neighborhood and ditched myself out of view and saw them pursuing through the neighborhood.” 
Hardison is claiming entrapment and says the cops should stop dedicating so many resources to marijuana investigations. 
“They’re after me because they want a big fish,” Hardison said. “There are a ton of drugs in Jackson Hole, and I am certainly not supplying them. They have other drugs and other people they should be pursuing, real gangsters. People die from alcohol, tobacco, heroin, meth and cocaine.” 
Hardison, 47, is best known for challenging U.S. drug laws and spending time in prison for running a European LSD lab. 
In various articles he’s referred to as a semifamous drug wizard and a chemist. 
“My intention is to launch a constitutional assault through the state of Wyoming against the entire Controlled Substances Act in the federal system,” Hardison said. “The war on drugs is not a war on drugs. It’s a war on some people who use some drugs.” 
Hardison says dash cam video or nearby surveillance will back up his story as to what happened Aug. 6. 
“It would have played out differently if they had effectively played their game,” Hardison said. “They didn’t box me in.” 
Police said the investigation into Hardison started in June 2017 when a confidential informant bought a pound of marijuana from him. 
They arranged another undercover deal in March 2017, according to documents. 
Several DCI agents were involved in the Hardison sting. 
Agents have also been busy investigating stores in the state that are selling cannabidol products, saying they are illegal because they have trace amounts of THC. 
Stores like Jackson Whole Grocer and Lucky’s Market pulled their CBD products earlier this month after agents with DCI said they could face criminal charges. 
“Who in their command structure has such an anal-retentive view?” Hardison said. “Maybe they should use a CBD repository and transform their point of view.” 
Deputy Director of DCI Forrest Williams said their drug investigations involve all illegal substances. 
“We work violations under the Controlled Substance Act and that includes all the substances that are illegal,” Williams said. “The majority of our cases are methamphetamine cases.” 
A warrant was issued for Hardison’s arrest on Aug. 8 on several counts of delivery and aggravated assault and battery. 
Contact Emily Mieure at 732-7066, courts@jhnewsandguide.com or @JHNGcourts. 
Casey Hardison

title: Cops say drug suspect eluded them in chase
story:
An undercover special agent bought $6,000 worth of drugs from Casey Hardison on Monday night, but when his backup officers moved in to arrest the suspect, Hardison took off. 
The exchange almost resulted in two special agents being run over by Hardison, cops reported, and launched a high-speed chase through the town of Jackson. 
Monday’s sting was planned after a year of undercover drug deals with Hardison, police said. 
A confidential informant bought a pound of marijuana from Hardison in June 2017. 
In March an undercover agent met with Hardison and bought 2 pounds of marijuana. 
“Hardison opened a black case, which Hardison took from the trunk of his car ... and removed two large, sealed packages of marijuana,” a probable cause affidavit states. 
On Monday night at 7:30 the same undercover agent met Hardison and two other people and arranged to buy 3 pounds of marijuana. 
The group hung out at a brewery until just after 9 p.m. and moved to a nearby intersection where the undercover officer bought five bags of pot for $6,000. 
Other agents of the Wyoming Division of Criminal Investigation and detectives of the Teton County Sheriff’s Office moved in and parked to block Hardison’s car, documents state. 
Hardison grabbed his steering wheel and started to drive off as police approached. 
“Special agents jumped from the path of Hardison’s vehicle to avoid being struck,” court records state. 
Police chased Hardison through Jackson. 
“As Hardison sped away a brief pursuit was conducted by law enforcement vehicles displaying emergency lights and sirens,” documents state. “Based on Hardison’s actions while driving, high speeds, numerous turns down streets and obvious disregard for the safety of the public, law enforcement ended any further attempts to stop Hardison’s vehicle.” 
Hardison has several pending delivery charges in Teton County, police said. A warrant for his arrest was pending Tuesday evening. 
Hardison is well known for his drug activity. The 47-year-old is a semi-famous LSD chemist who was sentenced to 20 years in prison for running a European LSD lab, according to a 2004 Vice article. 
Hardison was also a witness in a coroner’s inquest into the death of a local artist. Hardison was partying with Anthony Birkholz on the night he died. 
Hardison hosted a fundraiser in Jackson after Birkholz died. He also raised money online and promised to donate it to the Buffalo Field Campaign. But the memorial money ended up in police custody in Idaho after Hardison was arrested there last year for drug possession. 
The charges were later dismissed and prosecutors there said the cash was returned to Hardison. But employees at the Buffalo Field Campaign said they’ve never received the promised donation. Hardison said in January that he planned to raise the money by hosting an online blotter art sale, but an organizer said the sale didn’t go as planned. 
“I will keep raising money for the Buffalo Field Campaign as long as they exist and as long as I do,” Hardison told the News&Guide then. 
Contact Emily Mieure at 732-7066, courts@jhnewsandguide.com or @JHNGcourts. 
Casey Hardison

title: Senate approves bill to update penalties for marijuana edibles, vape pens
story:
Partially in response to several cases in the past few years in which people in possession of marijuana edibles have been given on misdemeanors because of current law, the Wyoming Senate passed a bill specifying penalties for nonplant form marijuana. 
The Wyoming Senate approved a bill specifying penalties for the possession of nonplant form marijuana by a vote of 19 to 11. 
Currently, Wyoming does not prosecute possession of nonplant form marijuana as a felony. Several cases, including one in Teton County, were thrown out or reduced from a felony to a misdemeanor last year because state law only applied to the plant form of the drug. 
“This does create an interesting situation with this ruling by the court that I want to clarify,” Teton County Deputy Prosecutor Clark Allan said during Daniel Bates’ sentencing in Teton County last year. “A person can come through with 4 ounces of plant form marijuana and be convicted of a felony and sent to the penitentiary, but if a person has an 18-wheeler full of gummy candies, it’s just a misdemeanor.” 
Should the bill pass, possession of no more than 0.3 grams of liquid marijuana, 3 grams of resin or 3 ounces of another form of nonplant-form marijuana products would carry a misdemeanor charge resulting in no more than one year in prison and no more than a $1,000 fine. 
Anything more than the weights listed above would result in a felony charge. 
Conviction of third misdemeanor offense would carry an increased penalty of no more than five years in prison and no more than a $5,000 fine. 
Contact Tom Hallberg at 732-5902 or thallberg@jhnewsandguide.com.

title: CBD oils pulled from store shelves
story:
Jackson Whole Grocer was asked to pull CV Sciences’ CBD oil from its shelves after the product tested positive for THC. 
Jackson Whole Grocer had to pull CV Sciences’ CBD oil from its shelves. On Tuesday store employees turned away several people looking for it. 
Certain cannabidiol products have disappeared from shelves at Jackson Whole Grocer and Lucky’s Market after the stores received a visit from police. 
An ongoing investigation has sparked a debate on the legality of the substance in Wyoming. 
After being told the store would face charges if they didn’t pull CBD products, employees at Whole Grocer complied. 
“They were very kind,” Whole Grocer Vice President and General Manager Tom Scott said. “They didn’t come in here guns blazing.” 
The Wyoming Division of Criminal Investigation claims a product the stores were selling contains traceable amounts of THC, which it says makes it illegal to possess or sell. 
“They gave us seven days to get rid of it,” Whole Grocer Herbalist Heather Olson said. “We’re sad to see it go. It’s a great category for our department. It was a huge move forward for herbal medicine. But psychoactive chemicals in the product are not appropriate in Wyoming.” 
DCI agents say the only exception to possessing THC in Wyoming is if you have a “hemp extract registration card” issued by the Wyoming Department of Health. 
Those cards are rare, state officials said. 
One of the CBD products police say is testing positive for THC comes from CV Sciences, a CBD hemp-oil manufacturing and distributing company. 
“We will address this like any issue with our lobbyists and attorneys,” said Josh Hendrix, director of business development at CV Sciences. “It should be an easy conversation. But we need clear-cut legislation.” 
Hendrix disagrees with DCI on the product’s legality. 
“We don’t get our products from marijuana,” he said. “This has happened enough times that the misinterpretation gives us an opportunity to educate.” 
Olson said the product is popular with Whole Grocer customers. She turned away half a dozen customers on Tuesday alone. More than 50 bottles are now in a cardboard box in the back of the grocery store. 
CBD is often used by people who suffer from epilepsy, anxiety, depression, seizures and chronic pain. 
Olson said the stores will rely on the CBD companies to send certificates of analysis to confirm none of their other products have THC in them. 
Lucky’s Market also took products off shelves last week. 
“We’ve pulled the products in a gesture of good faith,” said store director Chris Martinez. “There were multiple brands we had to pull.” 
The Division of Criminal Investigation said lab analysis confirmed the presence of THC in “many of the items” it received. 
According to CV Sciences, CBD oil is derived from agricultural hemp, does not make you high and has “a remarkable safety profile.” 
The World Health Organization does not consider it a controlled substance. 
“Cannabidiol does not appear to have abuse potential or cause harm,” its website states. 
A World Health Organization expert committee continues to review the extracts. 
DCI Operations Commander Ronnie Jones told the News&Guide that his agents have been collecting CBD around Wyoming since late last year. 
“We are still conducting an investigation,” Jones said. 
DCI Deputy Director of Operations Forrest Williams said the investigation began because of inquiries from the public and law enforcement officers about CBD’s legality. 
“We have bought from stores in Casper, Cheyenne, Laramie, Gillette, Rock Springs, and whatever products we’ve bought we submit them to the lab for testing, and if it contains any amount of THC it’s illegal,” Williams said. 
Jones wouldn’t say that the ongoing investigation is a priority for DCI. But several agents around the state are involved. 
“They are wasting their time,” Hendrix said. “This is a very disruptive thing. Cannabis has been demonized for so long. I’ve grown hemp on my farm. You can’t get high off it.” 
Hendrix says the investigation is based off misinformation. 
“They have bigger things to worry about,” he said. “There are hard drugs on the steeets. This doesn’t harm anyone. It helps people.” 
Hendrix says his company plans to clear it up any confusion surrounding levels of THC in their products and where it comes from. 
“It’s kind of like decaf coffee or Kombucha,” Hendrix said. “There are kids that take this product.” 
Contact Emily Mieure at 732-7066, courts@jhnewsandguide.com or @JHNGcourts.

title: Blotter, May 2
story:
Hungry kids: At least four teenagers have tried to steal donuts from the grocery store this week. Officers have given several middle schoolers trespass notices for the attempted thefts. In most cases their parents were called to come get them. In at least one case a juvenile was cited for shoplifting. 
Too close for comfort: A man called police at 7:50 p.m. April 24 because he said a man erratically driving a pickup almost ran him over. The driver was heading toward Jackson from Grand Teton National Park and failed field sobriety tests after officers stopped him. The 42-year-old was arrested on charges of DUI, driving without a license, driving without insurance and speeding. 
Environmentally friendly pothead: Recycling center employees found a marijuana pipe and a baggie with suspected marijuana from a bin they picked up from Jackson Hole High School. The pipe is recyclable, but police took the drugs for destruction. 
Nosy neighbor: Someone called police April 25 because a neighbor was smoking pot in his apartment. Officers confiscated a pipe, a half-gram of marijuana and hash oil. 
Nontraditional funeral: Someone honored their dead dog by wrapping it in a blanket and leaving it near Mosquito Creek covered in rose petals, but police were called because no one buried the fallen pooch. Leaving carcasses and unnatural objects like blankets in the forest is frowned upon. 
Illegal variety pack: Just before midnight Thursday officers stopped a car near the entrance of the National Elk Refuge. Two people told police they were looking for a place to camp. Officers smelled marijuana, and the driver said he has a medical marijuana card and works in the cannabis industry in Colorado. Police located dispensary containers, a glass container with THC wax, a container of a coconut oil and THC mixture, a dropper bottle and a vape pen. The 25-year-old was arrested and charged with two felony counts of possession and one misdemeanor count. 
Rookie mistake: A man driving a box truck tried to park in the parking garage but ran into the structure and its clearance sign. The collision caused damage to the building and the truck, but the man took off without reporting it. As of Monday police had located the truck, but the suspect had not received a citation. 
Drunken intellectual: A heavily intoxicated man passed out on his keyboard at Teton County Library. Library employees called police because the man was unresponsive. Officers had to remove the man’s headphones to get his attention. His portable breath test registered 0.30 percent blood alcohol content, and he was arrested for public intoxication. 
What was the first job you had as a teen?: Two teenagers were arrested around 10:15 p.m. Friday with 170 grams of marijuana, glass pipes, rolling papers, razor blades, wire filters, a scale and $850 cash. A 17-year-old was arrested for felony possession and intent to deliver. The other 17-year-old was charged with misdemeanor possession. 
Late-night frosty dreams: A man was passed out in his driver’s seat in the Wendy’s drive-thru at 2:30 a.m. Sunday, and when officers tapped on his window he sped off. A short pursuit ensued until the man pulled over and told police he “freaks out when he sees reds and blues.” Surprisingly, the man wasn’t drunk. But he was arrested for eluding police.

title: U.S. House of Representatives
story:
Three Republicans and two Democrats are competing for Wyoming’s sole seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. One of each party will advance. 
Liz Cheney (R, incumbent) 
Prior to serving in Congress, Liz Cheney practiced law and worked at the U.S. State Department. In the U.S. House she has supported legislation to crack down on illegal immigration, expand concealed carry and defund Planned Parenthood. 
“I have championed conservative reform to create jobs, cut taxes and regulation, expand America’s energy, mining and ag industries and restore the strength and power of our nation’s standing in the world,” Cheney said. 
She said she’ll work to reduce federal overreach, streamline regulations and return authority to states and local communities on public lands. 
Rod Miller (R) 
Rod Miller grew up on a Wyoming ranch and has worked on natural resources and federal lands in the offices of Wyoming Govs. Ed Herschler and Mike Sullivan. 
“I have a deep understanding of how good government should operate in the Cowboy State, as well as issues crucial to the state gained from that experience,” he said. 
He supports the heaviest tax burden for those with the greatest wealth, separating religion from politics, legalization of marijuana, keeping public lands public, women’s rights and reducing defense spending while maintaining a strong military. 
Blake Stanley (R) 
Blake Stanley is a self-described “blue-collar conservative.” He’s pro-life and believes in limited government that allows business and industry to lead the Wyoming economy. 
“As a veteran, I think we have an obligation to take care of our nation’s protectors — from the day they enter service until the day they graduate from this earth,” Stanley said on his website. 
He supports border security, bolstering the military, and the federal government “stepping back” to give Wyoming control over its natural resources. 
Travis Helm (D) 
Travis Helm, a Laramie-based immigration attorney, touts his “solid Wyoming” connections and credentials. 
Helm said he’ll choose Wyoming priorities ahead of any national party agenda: “By being independent, I will make Wyoming’s vote actually worth something, and we will be able to negotiate the best outcomes for our state.” 
He cares about maintaining public lands, public universal health care and providing for rural health care, diversifying the state economy, and investing in infrastructure. He supports repealing Citizens United and fixing immigration laws. 
Greg Hunter (D) 
Greg Hunter is a Laramie businessman who has also worked with government agencies in Washington, D.C. 
“After 30-plus years working for federal agencies and public lands, I have the skills and experience to protect our lands, navigate legislation, and save the taxpayer money while achieving the goals important to Wyomingites,” he said. “Wyoming can be progressive and still maintain its Cowboy character.” 
He supports universal health care, compassionate immigration reform, overturning Citizens United, diversifying Wyoming’s economy, defending public lands, legalizing marijuana, and some regulation of guns. 
—Allie Gross 
Contact Allie Gross at 732-7063, county@jhnewsandguide.com or @JHNGcounty.

title: Blotter, Aug. 1
story:
Friends through the good and bad: A man was pulled over at 2:30 a.m. July 23 for speeding. The 21-year-old Victor, Idaho, man admitted to having a few beers and had an open Modelo in the car. The man was arrested on charges of DUI, open container, driving without a valid license and speeding. His passenger, a 22-year-old Jackson man, had the chance to take a cab home but said he’d rather go to jail with his friend. He was booked on a charge of public intoxication. 
Odor eaters: A man pulled over for speeding tried to cover the smell of marijuana in his car with cologne and air freshener, police said. The 24-year-old was cited for possession and released. 
Cut off: A drunk man became so disruptive at The Wort Hotel after the bartender wouldn’t serve him more drinks that the cops were called and other patrons started to leave. “When he finally left he started yelling at people on the sidewalk in a threatening manner,” said Jackson police Lt. Roger Schultz. The 49-year-old Los Angeles man was arrested on charges of public intoxication and breach of peace. 
Whiskey and guns: Someone called police July 24 to report “a group of kids drinking whiskey and shooting guns” up Curtis Canyon. When deputies arrived they found the men, but they weren’t drunk, and they were shooting rounds legally. However, one of them had a warrant out for his arrest, so he was taken to jail, Teton County sheriff’s Sgt. Todd Stanyon said. 
Cotton candy with a side of pot: Some contract workers who were in town to sell food to patrons at the Teton County Fair were caught with over 648 grams of marijuana, police said. A 26-year-old male and a 25-year-old female, both from Arizona, were arrested on felony possession charges. 
Friendly drunks: Police stopped two people staggering down the middle of the road Thursday. The couple couldn’t keep their balance, reports stated. “We are drunk,” the man told officers. The 50-year-old Utah man failed a 20-step test, so he was arrested on a charge of public intoxication. 
Counting sheep: A man and woman were passed out in someone’s driveway Sunday, using a car’s tire for a pillow. “They were taking a dirt nap right there,” Schultz said. The two were drunk and didn’t want to drive, so they decided to sleep in a stranger’s driveway, reports said. They were arrested on charges of public intoxication. 
Caught in the act: An officer observed a man acting suspicious around 3:25 a.m. Saturday. The man was standing near a bike rack and looking around. The man then took one of the bikes and started riding off. An officer stopped the man and asked him if he’d stolen the bike. At first he claimed it was his friend’s bike. Then he admitted to lying and said he would put the bike back. “I’m just trying to go home, man,” he told the officer. The man was arrested on a charge of public intoxication.

title: Talk to your kids about smoking marijuana
story:
Marijuana is, according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, the most commonly used illegal psychoactive substance in the world. In the United States, of course, marijuana is subject to changing state and often contradictory federal laws. 
Marijuana is increasingly being legalized for medical and recreational use around the U.S., and child health advocates expect this will result in an increase in its use among teens. Already 55 percent of U.S. high school seniors report having tried marijuana. Twenty-three percent report current ongoing use, and 6 percent report daily use or signs of addiction. 
The tricky thing about marijuana is that it defies categorization. It’s legal yet illegal. It’s natural yet medical. It’s safe yet harmful. All of these statements are simultaneously true. Such contradictory and nuanced ideas can be hard for parents to keep straight in their head, let alone an adolescent. 
Most parents would prefer that their adolescents not use marijuana, and experts strongly agree. However, beginning and ending a discussion about marijuana with, “It’s bad for you,” is unlikely to be effective. The conversation will probably require some nuance, like our understanding of pot itself. 
Open a discussion. Like in any talk with a teen, it’s best to be non-confrontational. Maybe ask, “Have you heard about anyone at school smoking pot?” 
Solicit and listen to your teens’ viewpoints without judgment. “What do you think people like about weed?” Or, “What do you like about weed?” It’s OK to recognize that the euphoric feeling one can get from a cannabis high is a legitimate thing to like. 
On the other hand, maybe they like it because it’s a way to self-medicate depression, anxiety or sleep problems. Maybe it’s to fit in, or maybe it’s because they don’t fit in. The opposite of addiction is community, or so substance abuse experts say. 
It’s certainly true that marijuana can be used as medicine. Research studies have shown that it can help those with chronic pain, side effects from chemotherapy, seizures, and perhaps glaucoma. Marijuana is certainly a safer medicine for chronic pain than narcotics. If adolescents are having chronic pain, however, they should be working with a doctor to fix the underlying cause. 
Next, ask what they don’t like about marijuana. It can make you feel anxious or paranoid. It decreases your short-term memory and attention span. It slows down your motor control, coordination, reaction time and judgment. 
A major study also has shown that long-term marijuana use initiated in adolescence has negative effects on intellectual ability, such as executive function and processing speed, which do not recover by adulthood even when cannabis use is discontinued. 
Adolescent marijuana users are more likely to suffer depression, bipolar disorder, psychosis, and schizophrenia (data on anxiety disorder are mixed). Smoking marijuana decreases your lung function, even if smoke is inhaled through a vaporizer, and may increase your risk of heart attacks and strokes. It lowers sperm count and causes tooth and gum disease. 
Of note, I do not include the “gateway drug” theory among the known risks of marijuana here. This idea has increasingly been supplanted by the “common liability” theory; current studies suggest pre-existing genetic and environmental factors contribute to all substance abuse disorders. Therefore, specific use of any given drug at one time does not cause abuse of other substances later. Also, although cannabis smoke contains many of the same carcinogens as that of tobacco, it has not been definitively shown to cause cancer. 
So we can all come to the conclusion that marijuana has its good, but it also has its bad. Most experts believe that the bad clearly outweighs the good. This is especially true for adolescents, whose prefrontal cortex will continue to develop until their mid-20s. 
If your teens haven’t been exposed to marijuana yet, ask them to think about their personal reasons for using or not using the substance. Give them information to back it up. Ask them to think about what they would say if they were ever in a peer pressure situation — they could even rehearse the conversation with you. 
If your teen is smoking pot already, respectfully explore their perceptions. Just because marijuana is “medicinal” and “natural” doesn’t mean it’s safe. Opiates like morphine are medicines naturally derived from poppies, yet they and their synthetic cousins were responsible for over 42,000 overdose deaths in the U.S. in 2016. 
If your teens already smoke marijuana you could challenge them to stop marijuana use for a defined period of time. Treat it as an experiment, to see how they feel different. If they can’t or won’t stop, that’s a red flag for a true substance abuse disorder. If they do stop, follow up with them at the end of the experiment. If things didn’t go well, explore why. 
At any time in this process, it’s a good idea to include your pediatrician in the discussion. Hopefully you and your child have developed a personal relationship with a doctor specifically trained in working with adolescents who can have a confidential discussion with your teen. 
The pediatrician can determine if criteria are met for a true substance use disorder, assess for indications that the teen might be self-medicating, and use proven techniques to help the teen make healthy decisions. When needed, the pediatrician can refer to another mental health professional with the tools to address the problem. The pediatrician can determine if the teen, or anyone else, is at imminent risk of harm (in this case, it might be necessary for the doctor to break confidentiality with the teen.) The American Academy of Pediatrics and many other national organizations consistently caution against involuntary drug testing in adolescents. 
Marijuana is a complicated topic with inherent contradictions; it warrants a candid, nonthreatening dialogue between parents and teens. 
Dr. Travis Riddell, owner of Jackson Pediatrics, is part of a team of doctors who write about children’s health for the News&Guide. Contact him via columnists@jhnewsandguide.com. 
Travis Riddell 
I have just a small issue with a statement in the third paragraph:  "It's natural yet medicinal".........It should read: "It's natural and medicinal".  I don't know what proportion of our medicines are derived from and synthesized from plants, but, correct me if I'm wrong, perhaps the majority of our medicines come from "natural" plants.  Therefore, it is certainly no surprise that it is natural yet medicinal.

title: Blotter, April 11
story:
Bangkok noodle bandit: A man who was splurging on drinks and dinner at Teton Tiger last week “ran out the door” when he was given his $51.94 check, police said. It happened around 7:30 p.m. April 2, and police said they have a lead on who the thief might be. 
BBQ clobber: Police responded to Moe’s BBQ on April 2 around midnight after a woman punched another woman in the face. “The two females went there and got into an argument about one of their boyfriends,” Jackson police Lt. Roger Schultz said. “The argument was followed by a knuckle sandwich to the face.” The victim wasn’t seriously injured, but police are searching for the 30-year-old suspect. 
They’re onto you: Someone ordered almost $800 worth of skin care products with someone else’s credit card and sent them to the card owner’s house. “It’s not uncommon for scammers to send it to the correct address and then try to intercept it,” Schultz said. The card owner reported the fraudulent charges to police and returned the beauty products. 
No off-roading in town: A man was pulled over around midnight April 4 after he plowed through someone’s yard to turn westbound on Karns Avenue. The 25-year-old parked at Snow King Motel and refused to do any field sobriety tests but was arrested on a DUI charge anyway. 
Pick a room, any room: Four young adults were busted April 4 for trespassing and partying in a hotel room at the Virginian Lodge. The room was supposed to be unoccupied, but one of the individuals at the party had somehow acquired a room key. An 18-year-old female from Grover was arrested on a Lincoln County warrant and for being a minor in possession of alcohol. 
Grandma’s greens: A car was pulled over for going 47 mph in a 30 zone around 10:30 a.m. Saturday. The officer smelled marijuana, but the driver claimed she didn’t have any. Police found six marijuana cigarettes in the center console. The 63-year-old Bondurant woman was cited for speeding and possession and released on scene. 
Fresh dumpings: Some employees at the Lockhart Ranch called police on Sunday and said a person in an RV has been dumping human feces into their ditch. The individuals in the camper were warned, and they agreed to move on. 
Let’s get this over with, officer: A driver was pulled over after midnight Friday for going 33 mph in a 25 zone and for not coming to a complete stop at a red flashing light. Officers made contact with the man and smelled alcohol, reports said. The 53-year-old admitted to having a beer before driving, and during field sobriety tests he asked the officer, “How about we just go to jail?” The Blackfoot, Idaho, man was charged with driving without a license, open container and DUI.

title: Erin Kay Endres
story:
Erin Kay Endres, 37, of Rock Springs, died on Tuesday, Aug. 14, 2018. She was a lifelong resident of Rock Springs. 
She was was born on Dec. 22, 1980, in Rock Springs, and was the daughter of Charles Phillip and Cathy Jolene McQuillan Endres. 
She attended schools in Rock Springs and graduated from the Rock Springs High School in 1998. 
Following cremation a celebration of life will be at 6 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 22, 2018, at the Old American Legion, 543 Broadway, Rock Springs.

title: Marijuana comes with many dangers
story:
Recently, while seated in a doctor’s office, I picked up a free booklet by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, National Institutes of Health entitled “Marijuana Facts for Teens.” I learned many facts that bear repeating in our world where 7 percent of American youth used marijuana last month.

title: Alice Putman
story:
Alice Putman passed away on Monday, Aug. 6, 2018. 
Alice was born in Rock Springs to Ernest and Frances Anselmi. She had two younger brothers. Her parents and brothers predeceased her. After graduation from high school, Alice went to Lincoln, Nebraska, to study nursing at St. Elizabeth School of Nursing. 
Alice met Dale Putman on her 20th birthday. It was Dale’s 21st birthday, and they share the same birthday. They married at the cathedral in Lincoln on Sept. 8, 1951. They celebrated 66 years of marriage. Alice and Dale have seven children — Mark, Lee, Neil, Bruce, Kirk, Nancy and Wendy. They have 17 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. 
After their marriage, they moved to Sioux City, Iowa, where they lived for 25 years. While in Iowa, Alice served on the Hoover School PTA Board and was president of the Confraternity at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church. Alice was also a Girl Scout leader and a Cub Scout den mother. 
The family moved to Leawood, Kansas, in 1976. Alice served as president of Leawood Welcomers and on the board of Sister Cities of Leawood and Yilan, Taiwan. Alice and Dale have been members of Cure of Ars Catholic Church for 42 years. She held many offices at Cure of Ars including president of the Woman’s Club, sacristan and Eucharistic minister. 
In addition to raising seven children, Alice loved to play golf and garden. Red roses were her favorite flower. She loved reading, playing bridge and watching old movies and “Jeopardy!” Alice loved to travel with her husband, mother, daughters and grandchildren. She took her grandchildren on trips of their choice including Europe, China, Australia and South Africa. She visited most U.S. states and 66 countries. Alice enjoyed spending time at her condo in Scottsdale, Arizona, where one of her daughters and two grandsons live. She loved celebrating Independence Day in the mountains of Colorado with all her family. Alice hosted wonderful large family dinners for holidays and birthdays. 
Visitation will be from 9-10 a.m. Saturday, Aug. 11, 2018, with funeral Mass at 10 a.m. at Cure of Ars Catholic Church, 9405 Mission Road, Leawood, Kansas. Entombment will be in Resurrection Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, Alice suggested donations to Catholic Charities food pantry or Catholic Community Hospice. Condolences may be expressed at www.porterfuneralhome.com. Porter Funeral Homes & Crematory, 8535 Monrovia, Lenexa, Kansas, is in charge of arrangements.

title: Courts
story:
JOSHUA J. KNIGGE, 18, pleaded guilty June 8 to taking drugs into jail, a felony, and misdemeanor counts of interference with a peace officer and use of a controlled substance. A count of minor in possession of tobacco was dismissed as part of a plea agreement. Knigge was seen Sept. 21 at the Walgreens parking lot smoking a cigarette, but police knew that he was underage and that he had a probation revocation warrant against him. When the truck pulled into Common Cents to get gas, the officer tried to talk to Knigge, but the teen gave a false name, was uncooperative, got out of the truck without permission, resisted arrested and was belligerent. At jail, he was found with a rubber pipe with burnt marijuana inside, according to court documents.

title: High stakes
story:
Ali Kistler, 24, poses for a portrait at Half Pipe Alley on Wednesday afternoon. She bought marijuana in Colorado, where recreational use of marijuana is legal, and was caught with it in Gillette, where it’s illegal. 
K-9 Officer Trevor Johnson searches a bag with his dog, Lord, on Saturday morning after finding marijuana on a passenger on a Jefferson Lines bus while parked at the Shell Gas Station on Highway 14-16. Along with an increase in finding marijuana from Colorado, local officers also routinely find pot and paraphernalia on buses coming through from Oregon and Washington, where recreational marijuana use also is legal. 
Drug paraphernalia sits on the ground outside the Shell Gas Station on Highway 14-16 after it was found on a person on a bus Saturday morning. 
Trevor Johnson searches a bag with his K-9 Lord after finding marijuana on a person at the Shell Gas Station on Saturday morning. 
Ali Kistler, 24, skates around the skate park near the Campbell County Public Library on Wednesday afternoon. 
Ali Kistler, 24, skates around the Half Pipe Alley skate park near the Campbell County Public Library on Wednesday afternoon. Kistler has been skating since she was 13 years old. 
Ali Kistler, 24, skates around the skate park near the public library on Wednesday afternoon. Kistler has been skating since she was 13 years old. 
K-9 Officer Trevor Johnson leads Lord around a storage room on a practice drug search Friday afternoon. 
K-9 Officer Trevor Johnson leads Lord on a practice drug search. 
Police Officer Vavi Domingo searches a bag for drugs Saturday morning. 
Police Officer Vavi Domingo hands drug paraphernalia to K-9 Officer Trevor Johnson as they search a bag for drugs Saturday morning at the Highway 14-16 Shell Station. 
Lord rests with his toy after completing a practice drug search Friday afternoon. K-9 Officer Johnson has been working with Lord for almost three years. Each month, Lord and Johnson complete a minimum of 16 hours of training. 
K-9 Officer Trevor Johnson gives Lord a break between practice searches Friday afternoon. Lord is the only German shepherd police dog with the Gillette Police Department. 
K-9 Officer Johnson plays with Lord after completing a practice drug search Friday afternoon. 
K-9 Officer Johnson gives Lord a treat after he successfully found an object during an evidence search Friday afternoon. 
K-9 Officer Johnson gives Lord a treat after he successfully found an object during an evidence search Friday afternoon. Johnson scattered four pieces of evidence around the field for Lord to find. After the final found item, Lord receives a toy as a reward so he knows the task is over. 
K-9 Officer Johnson and Lord sit in their police vehicle. 
K-9 Officer Johnson leads Lord around a storage room on a practice drug search Friday afternoon. Johnson hid four kinds of drugs in varying amounts around the room and Lord successfully found them all within five minutes. Lord is considered a dual-purpose K-9 as he can detect narcotics as well as perform tracking and building searches. 
When Ali Kistler was pulled over for not having her taillights on a Saturday night in September, she knew she would be arrested. 
As a sheriff’s deputy checked her driver’s license, she could smell the 2 ounces of marijuana that Kistler had bought at Denver dispensaries and brought on her visit to Gillette.

title: Courts
story:
LUERIE L. WILLIAMS, 38, was sentenced July 23 to eight to 12 years in prison for delivery of marijuana, but that sentence was suspended in favor of a 365-day split sentence in county jail (credit for 183 days served) and 12 years of supervised probation. District Judge Michael N. “Nick” Deegan also fined her $2,860 and ordered her to complete high-intensity residential substance abuse treatment. Williams was involved in the sale of $280 worth of meth to a confidential informant with the Sheriff’s Office on May 12, 2016. She also had been charged with supplying money to a woman to buy large amounts of meth between May 2014 and March 2015 to sell in Gillette, according to court documents.

title: Courts
story:
JONATHAN DAVID MUSSER, 33, pleaded guilty June 22 to felony possession of marijuana and misdemeanor possession of THC. In a plea agreement, attorneys will jointly recommend a deferred sentence and four years of supervised probation on the felony count and an imposed 10-day jail sentence on the misdemeanor. Musser was arrested Oct. 27 when police pulled over a minivan at about 9 p.m. because it didn’t have headlights. The police officer smelled marijuana and asked the five people inside the minivan about it. Near where Musser had been sitting, police found a baggie with 7.1 grams of marijuana and a backpack with 1 gram of hash and paraphernalia. A drug dog indicated on a black filing cabinet in his office downstairs during a subsequent search of his house. That turned up 23 bags of 1⁄4-ounce portions of marijuana totaling 5.58 ounces. Elsewhere in the home, police found a bottle of liquid THC weighing 26 grams, a digital scale and loose marijuana, according to court documents.

title: Blotter
story:
SECOND STREET: Officers pulled over Jamie Keefe, 39, for a broken brake light at about 9 p.m. Friday, Police Sgt. Jason Marcus said. She appeared to be under the influence of meth and a search of her car turned up two meth pipes containing meth residue, a jeweler’s bag containing meth residue and a liquid used for defrauding drug tests. Keefe performed poorly on field sobriety tests and was arrested. She was told that she couldn’t bring drugs into jail, but detention officers found 0.3 grams of marijuana in her purse. She was charged with three felonies: taking drugs into jail, possession of marijuana and possession of meth. She also was charged with five misdemeanors: using drugs, driving under the influence of drugs, not wearing a seat belt, having a broken brake light and possession of materials for defrauding a drug test, Marcus said.

title: Changes to cannabis laws unlikely
story:
CHEYENNE – Efforts to strengthen Wyoming’s marijuana laws are likely dead for now. 
The Wyoming Legislature has found itself at an impasse in the last several sessions over the issue. The Joint Judiciary Interim Committee passed two bills leading up to the 2018 budget session, one for each chamber, attempting to change marijuana laws. They were meant to address concerns put forth by law enforcement and courts with regard to products flowing in from Colorado, where recreational and medical use are legal. 
Wyoming’s laws were written several decades ago, when the plant form of the drug was by far the most prevalent manifestation. Today, in addition to concentrates such as shatter and wax, edible and liquid-infused products are increasingly commonplace. 
Wyoming law states possession of 3 ounces or more of marijuana in plant form is considered a felony in the state, but it lacks definition when it comes to other products that are often higher in the drug’s intoxicating ingredient, THC. 
“The dilemma for the Legislature is that two judges looked at a pile of (cannabis-infused) gummy bears and said, ‘I don’t see any green-leafy, therefore you can’t tell me that gummy is green-leafy,’” said Byron Oedekoven, executive director of the Wyoming Association of Sheriffs and Chiefs of Police. “So we have wrestled with defining that infused product, trying to come up with some equivalency to the green-leafy. Essentially, how many gummy bears does it take to make a felony?” 
Sarah Barrett of the Wyoming State Crime Lab reported to lawmakers in Wheatland last year that no new advances have been made since the 2017 session that might make it easier to discern how many doses are contained in a particular product. That led to some hesitancy on the part of lawmakers worried they would be voting for laws that could apply felony charges for relatively minor offenses. Add that to lawmakers who want to reform marijuana and cannabis laws to ease punishments and Wyoming has an impasse on changing its laws. 
The troubles for the bills in the House of Representatives came in the first week, when the chamber overwhelmingly voted against introducing the measure 49-10, with one excused. While the Senate’s measure passed with strong support throughout, it died a quiet death in the chamber down the hall when it was not introduced to the House’s Committee of the Whole. 
And it appears that is where the issue will lie for the foreseeable future. Oedekoven said this week it’s his understanding the Judiciary Committee has no interest in picking up the issue leading up to the 2019 general session. 
“(The Judiciary Committee said) we’ve beat this horse, we understand the issue,” he said. 
House Judiciary Committee Chairman Dan Kirkbride, R-Chugwater, said that’s probably accurate. 
“I think it has to do with not being able to accurately measure the THC,” Kirkbride said. “That process is not widely or inexpensively available, and there’s a number of legislators who would be reluctant to charge and incarcerate people if they think it’s done unfairly. We’ve worked on it for three to four years, and we’re just kind of stuck.” 
Though the 30-member Senate seems mostly on the same page on the issue, Kirkbride said it feels to him like the 60-member House is more divided. 
The Legislature’s Management Council, which includes House and Senate leadership, could direct the Judiciary Committee to address the issue, but there’s been no indication that will happen. The council meets in April to make several key determinations on the course of interim months. 
Oedekoven said it’s possible a review of the matter in the courts could provide some answers or better define penalties for cannabis-infused products. Individual lawmakers could also bring a bill forward in 2019. 
“I’m hoping they’ll deal with the issue, and deal with it correctly,” Oedekoven said.

title: Courts
story:
NICOLE GRAY LANDSEM, 19, and DENNIS ROBERT GONDER, 20, have been charged in Circuit Court with possession with intent to deliver marijuana, a felony. They were arrested April 16 after an anonymous caller to the Crime Stoppers tip line reported there was “a large amount of marijuana inside apartment #8” at 3506 Foothills Blvd., according to court documents. A police officer and his drug dog went to the apartments and the dog indicated drugs were present in apartment 8 after showing no interest in three other apartments. Gonder responded to the officer’s knock and the officer “could smell the overwhelming odor of raw marijuana,” according to an affidavit. After getting a search warrant, the officer found 7.5 ounces of marijuana concealed in a closet in the living room. Landsem said Gonder had gone to Colorado to buy the marijuana. Gonder said the only marijuana he knew about was shake on a couch cushion. Also in the apartment, police found 0.5 grams of psilocybin mushrooms in the kitchen and 0.2 grams of LSD in Landsem’s bedroom, according to court documents. Both also are charged with misdemeanor counts of possession of a controlled substance for psilocybin mushrooms. Landsem also is charged with misdemeanor possession of LSD.

title: Marijuana reform passes Senate
story:
Wyoming senators passed their marijuana reform bill Wednesday, which follows the House of Representatives killing its version of the bill in the Legislature’s first week. 
The Joint Judiciary Committee passed two bills during the interim, one for each chamber, attempting to reform marijuana laws to address several concerns put forth by law enforcement and courts. Wyoming lawmakers have tried and failed to address issues that have come up since Colorado began loosening laws on the drug in the last several legislative sessions. 
Products infused with cannabis, such as edibles and liquids, continue to vex policymakers in terms of what amounts constitute felonies. 
Sarah Barrett of the Wyoming State Crime Lab reported to lawmakers in November that no new advances have been made since the last session that might make it easier to discern the drug’s concentration in any particular product. This has led to some hesitancy on the part of lawmakers worried they would be voting for laws that could apply felony charges for relatively minor offenses. 
Currently, Wyoming law states possession of 3 ounces or more of marijuana in plant form is considered a felony in Wyoming. The bill would make it a felony to possess more than 36 ounces of a cannabis-infused liquid, more than 3 grams of cannabis concentrate products or more than 3 ounces of marijuana in another form. 
On Wednesday, Sen. Cale Case, R-Lander, proposed an amendment that would allow defendants to contend that a product they are charged with possessing doesn’t constitute a felony based on the amount of intoxicating elements in a product, such as an edible, at their own expense. 
Sen. Leland Christensen, R-Alta, Senate Judiciary Committee chairman, said he was against the amendment because he heard in testimony the testing wasn’t accurate enough to meet a legal standard. But Sen. Chris Rothfuss, D-Laramie, supported the amendment, arguing the testing is commonplace. It just hasn’t made its way into an affordable marketplace that would allow Wyoming law enforcement agencies to conduct regular testing, Rothfuss said. 
“The idea that we can’t do this when, for example, we can tell the concentration of certain gases on a star 100 million light years away — it’s absurd,” he said. 
But it wasn’t enough to convince senators to amend the bill, as it failed 13-17. The bill passed its third and final reading in the Senate 19-11. Laramie County Sens. Fred Emerich and Anthony Bouchard, both Republicans, voted “nay.” 
While the House apparently lacked the appetite to consider its own measure, it will now be up to that chamber to decide whether to pass Senate File 23.

title: Powell officials find pot in city planters
story:
City of Powell workers recently discovered a different kind of “weed” sprouting up in a couple of city planters: marijuana plants. 
Powell Police Chief Roy Eckerdt suspects someone slipped marijuana seeds into the city planters some time ago. 
Amid the other plants and flowers growing in the pots, city workers unknowingly watered and cared for the cannabis plants for a period of weeks before discovering a couple on the afternoon of June 29, Eckerdt said. 
“They recognized what it was once everything started to leaf out,” he said. 
City Parks and Recreation Superintendent Del Barton said the plants were difficult for his seasonal workers to distinguish at first. 
“To be honest with you, and to be fair, without having a marijuana field testing kit, I can’t tell the difference between hemp and marijuana,” Barton said with a chuckle. “But it sure looked like marijuana to me.” 
Barton’s workers pulled the plants and took them to police. A couple days later, another plant was found, bringing the total to three plants in three different pots. 
“They [the workers] just mentioned to me this morning that in the course of watering, they think — though we’re not sure yet — that there may be some additional ones popping up,” Barton said Wednesday. 
While the chief can only speculate on the intent behind the clandestine plantings, “my guess is that’s somebody’s sense of humor,” Eckerdt said.

title: Guns, God, weed and land: Survey reveals public opinion on legislative issues
story:
A new survey asked Wyomingites for their opinions on a number of hot-button issues facing the Wyoming Legislature this session — including public lands, marijuana, “stand your ground” legislation and separation of church and state. 
While many of the proposed bills relating to these issues have already failed, others are still in play, and Brian Harnisch — a senior research scientist with the Wyoming Survey and Analysis Center — said the survey could provide valuable information to state lawmakers. 
“A lot of time, at the state, what we hear is anecdotal evidence about what constituents may or may not feel, so what we wanted to do is provide a tool that can actually ... say, ‘This is what the citizens of Wyoming as a whole feel about these issues,’” Harnisch said. 
While most surveys conducted by WYSAC take weeks or months to complete, the 2018 Legislative Session Survey of Wyoming Citizens was fielded in four days, gathering responses from 694 survey completions, while using an online probability-based panel of respondents called WyoSpeaks. 
Harnisch said the panel ensures everyone in Wyoming has an equal chance of being asked to participate. 
“The WyoSpeaks panel is a tool we’ve been developing for almost two years now — the idea being that we build a probability panel of Wyoming citizens to enable us to do these fast-turnaround, low-cost, web-based surveys that produce statistically valid results,” he said. 
Though the legislative-issues survey is the first publication based on the WyoSpeaks panel, WYSAC has performed “test runs” before. 
“We’ve tested the panel — against our scientifically-rigorous telephone survey results for the same questions — to make sure that we got results that were statistically valid and comparable to those really robust, scientifically rigorous methodology questions,” Harnisch said. 
He added he hopes the survey and future similar surveys will be used by state legislators to gauge public opinion. Given the quick turnaround time and low cost of WyoSpeaks panel survey, Harnisch said the survey could be deployed more frequently and maybe even multiple times throughout the year. 
“As we develop this — this is still in its infancy — I’d like to have more of a partnership with the Legislature,” he said. “(If) we know about some issues that might be coming up, we can actually get a bit of a head start and try to get this information out to the Legislature as a service to them to make sure they’re informed about what the citizens of the state actually feel about the issues.” 
Public lands 
The survey found Wyoming residents were divided on issues related to the transfer of public lands, with 43 percent saying they support the transfer of federal lands to the state and 41 percent saying they oppose. There was a similar split on whether the state could financially handle the management of land being transferred. 
However, a majority of residents — 71 percent — said they oppose the state selling off public lands to raise revenue for the management of remaining lands, and an even greater majority — 76 percent — said they oppose the state selling off public lands to reduce budget deficits. 
More than half — 55 percent — agree the state could do a better job of managing public lands in Wyoming than the federal government. 
A plurality — 47 percent — said they would support an amendment clarifying how the state would handle public lands transferred from federal to state control. House Bill 131 — which speaks to this issue — failed introduction Feb. 14. 
Marijuana 
A majority of residents — 70 percent — support medical marijuana and oppose jail time for minor possession convictions, but residents are divided on issues of recreational marijuana, according to the study. 
A plurality — 49 percent — said they oppose allowing adults to legally possess marijuana for personal use, while 43 percent support it. 
A proposed house bill seeking to establish penalties for edible marijuana products failed introduction one day before the survey period began, but a senate file providing for similar penalties has passed the Senate and been referred to committee in the House. 
The survey finds residents are divided on the issue, with 33 percent saying they support a bill with such penalties but 37 saying they oppose such a bill. 
‘Stand your ground’ 
Senate File 71, which would introduce “stand your ground” legislation to state statute, has considerable support in the Legislature. Sponsored by Sen. Anthony Bouchard, R-Cheyenne, the bill has 22 co-sponsors. 
The bill also has support from a majority — 62 percent — of residents, according to the study. Senate File 71 was passed by the Senate Wednesday and referred to committee in the House the next day. 
Cryptocurrency 
House Bill 70 — which would enable blockchain token, or cryptocurrency, trading in Wyoming — has citizens divided, with 18 percent saying they support it and 29 percent saying they oppose it, and more than half refusing to take a side — 28 percent of survey respondents say they neither support nor oppose it, while 25 percent say they don’t know or are not sure. 
The bill was passed unanimously by the House and passed second reading in the Senate on Thursday. 
‘In God We Trust’ 
A proposed bill requiring classrooms, school libraries, the state capitol building and other state-owned or leased buildings to display “In God We Trust” passed in the House and has been referred to committee in the Senate. A majority of Wyoming residents — 54 percent — said they support the bill, while 30 percent said they oppose it. 
Stalking laws 
House Bill 8 — which would increase the punishments for stalking and was passed by both chambers — is supported by 83 percent of Wyoming residents, according to the study. 
Taxes 
The study polled respondents on a number of tax proposals brought before the State Legislature this session, though the most popular bills are already dead. 
A majority of Wyoming residents — 71 percent — said they support increasing the cigarette tax, while 70 percent supported increasing the tax on moist snuff. A bill doing both failed introduction Feb. 16, the day the survey began. 
A bill increasing the tax on alcohol — supported by 64 percent of Wyoming residents — similarly failed introduction. The Legislature also killed a statewide lodging tax supported by a majority — 53 percent — of Wyoming residents. 
A wind energy production tax hike, which divided residents, is also dead. While 40 percent of respondents said they support the bill, 34 percent said they oppose it. 
A tax cut for the oil and gas industry — which is supported by 51 percent of Wyoming residents, according to the study — is still alive, having passed in the Senate and referred to committee in the House.

title: On the Record: Aug. 18
story:
Cheyenne man arrested for felony possession of controlled substance 
A Laramie Police Department officer on routine patrol stopped a vehicle at 11:36 a.m. Wednesday in the 800 block of University Avenue for a license plate violation. As a result of the traffic stop and the officer’s subsequent investigation, the driver and both passengers in the vehicle were arrested, according to a news release. 
The two passengers were charged with misdemeanor crimes. The driver, Joshua T. Hancock, a 31-year-old Cheyenne resident, was charged with a third-offense possession of controlled substance — marijuana. 
At this time, Hancock’s bond has not been set and he remains incarcerated at the Albany County Detention Center. 
Possession of controlled substance, third or subsequent offense, is a felony punishable by imprisonment for a term of up to five years, a fine of up to $5,000 or both. 
Albany County Detention Center

Registered sex offenders 
The Albany County Sheriff’s Office, in cooperation with the Laramie Boomerang, advises residents that state law requires notification if a registered sex offender is living within a minimum of 750 feet of certain areas, which includes residences, and organizations within the community such as schools, churches and religious and/or youth organizations. 
This is not a complete listing of all sex offenders in Albany County, but reflects the most current updated information. The below listed website can be accessed for more complete postings. 
Any person who uses this information or information accessed from the Wyoming Sex Offender Registry to harass any individual, including the person’s family members, or misuses the information might be subject to criminal prosecution or civil liability under federal or state law. 
No determination has been made that any individual in the registry is currently dangerous. Individuals included in the registry are there solely by virtue of their conviction record and state law. 
The main purpose of providing information on the internet and through the newspaper is to ensure information is publicly available and accessible, not to warn about any specific individual. 
Go to www.wysors.dci.wyo.gov/sor/ for specific information and photographs of the listed offenders. Call the Albany County Sheriff’s Office at 755-3520 with additional questions. 
— 
Brandon Busch: 276 Wyoming Highway 230, No. 69

title: On the Record: July 12
story:
Laramie resident arrested for domestic battery, false imprisonment 
Laramie Police Department officers responded at about 7 p.m. Friday to the 900 Block of North McCue for the report of a physical domestic, according to an LPD news release. 
As a result of the officers’ investigation, James E. Buchanan Jr., a 34-year-old Laramie resident, was arrested and charged with felony domestic battery and false imprisonment. At this time, Buchanan’s bond has been set at $1,000 and he remains incarcerated at the Albany County Detention Center. 
A person is guilty of false imprisonment if he or she knowingly and unlawfully restrains another so as to interfere substantially with his or her liberty. 
False imprisonment is a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for up to one year, a fine of up to $1,000 or both. 
A household member is guilty of domestic battery if he or she knowingly or recklessly causes bodily injury to another household member by use of physical force. 
Domestic battery is punishable by imprisonment for up to 10 years, a fine of up to $10,000 or both, if within the previous 10 years, the person has been convicted of domestic battery two or more times or has been convicted of domestic battery and any similar offense against another household member. 
Female arrested for burglary 
Laramie Police Department officers responded July 3 and July 4 to the 200 block of Baker Street for reports each day of a burglary, according to an LPD news release. 
As a result of the officers’ investigations, Cassidy Harper, a 20-year-old female from California, was arrested and charged with burglary and trespassing. Harper remains incarcerated at the Albany County Detention Center on a $500 bond. 
A person is guilty of burglary if, without authority, he or she enters or remains in a building, occupied structure or vehicle, or separately secured or occupied portion thereof, with intent to commit theft or a felony therein. 
Burglary is a felony punishable by imprisonment for up to 10 years, a fine of up tp $10,000 or both. 
Albany County Detention Center

title: Northern Wyoming Daily News - Serving the Big Horn Basin for over 100 years
story:
A Massachusetts medical marijuana dispensary has created a culinary delight for patients who don’t want to smoke their pot or eat it in the form of sweets. 
Quincy-based Ermont Inc. has been selling cannabis-infused pizza for about three weeks to rave reviews. 
Director of Operations Seth Yaffe says the company has a whole range of marijuana edibles, but he wanted to offer meals that patients could eat without a lot of sugar. 
The 6-inch cheese pizzas sell for $38 apiece. The tomato sauce contains 125 milligrams of THC, the psychoactive compound in marijuana. The company has sold about 200 already. Yaffe says if patients want toppings, they can add their own. 
Only people with state-issued medical marijuana ID cards are eligible to buy the pies.
